$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 90
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1314-56-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: S,S-Thioacetalization of carbonyl compounds
(general procedure): A mixture of carbonyl compounds (2 mmol), dithiol
(2.2 mmol) or thiol (4.4 mmol) and P2O5/SiO2 (5 mg) was stirred at
ambient temperature. After completion of reaction as checked by TLC, it
was diluted with n-hexane and the catalyst was filtered off. The filtrate
solution (50 ml) was washed with aqueous 10% NaOH (2 x 10 ml) solution
and then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The solvent was evaporated by
rotary evaporator and the crude product was purified through a column of
silica gel (n-hexane:EtOAc, 80:20) to obtain the pure product. Entry 9d,
yield 90%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, silica support used, reusable catalyst, no
solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Silica gel-supported phosphorus pentoxide: a reusable catalyst for
S,S-acetalization of carbonyl groups under ambient conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Shaterian, Hamid Reza; Azizi, Kobra; Fahimi, Nafiseh
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Sulfur Chemistry (2011), 32(1), 85-91

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-08-1
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 123-08-0
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 134836-75-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-307-CAS-11342805
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 90
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 10277-43-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Typical experimental procedure To a mixture of aldehyde (1 mmol) and
1,3-dithiol (1.1 mmol) or ethanethiol (2.2 mmol) was added finely
powdered La(NO3)3•6H2O (5 mol%) and the reaction was stirred under
solvent-free conditions at room temperature for an appropriate time
(table 1). After completion of the reaction as monitored by TLC, water
(10mL) was added to the reaction mixture and the product was extracted
into ethyl acetate (3 x 20 mL). The combined organic layer was washed
with brine solution, dried over anhydrous sodium sulphate and
concentrated under reduced pressure to give crude product, which was
purified over silica gel column to afford corresponding thioacetals.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM chemoselective, no solvent

$DATUM 75-08-1
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 123-11-5
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 23837-15-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-307-CAS-13434286
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 90
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 5952-71-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Thioacetalization under Solvent-Free
Conditions In a mortar, aldehyde or ketone (10 mmol) was added to a
mixture of 1,2-ethandithiol, 1,3-propandithiol, or ethylthiol (14 mmol)
and BTPTB (0.5 mmol 0.3 g). The reaction mixture was ground by pestle at
room temperature under solvent-free conditions. After disappearance of
starting material (monitored by thin-layer chromatography, TLC), the
mixture was washed with diethyl ether and filtered. The filtrate was
evaporated under reduced pressure, and the resulting crude material was
purified by column chroatography (EtoAc-n-hexane) to afford pure
dithioactas (Tables 1 and 2). 4'-Methoxyphenyl Diethyl Dithioacetal
(3e)[28] White solid, yield 90%. mp 43°C; IR (KBr): 2965, 2928, 1609,
1510, 1447, 1301, 1261, 1174, 1106, 1025 cm-1 . 1H NMR: δ = 1.22 (t,
J=7.3Hz, 6 H, 2 x SCH2CH3), 2.46-2.63 (m, 4 H, 2 x SCH2CH3), 3.80 (s, 3
H, OCH3), 4.91 (s, 1 H, ArCH), 6.85 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2 H, ArH), 7.37 (d,
J= 8.5Hz, 2 H, ArH) ppm. 13C NMR: δ = 14.24 (2 C), 26.15 (2 C), 51.69,
55.22, 113.75 (2 C), 128.77 (2 C), 132.37, 159.00 ppm. Anal. calcd. for
C12H18OS2 (242.41): C, 59.46; H, 7.48; S, 26.46%. Found: C, 59.60; H,
7.50; S, 26.20%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry, no solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Efficient method for thioacetalization of carbonyl compounds in the
presence of a catalytic amount of benzyltriphenylphosphonium tribromide
(BTPTB) under solvent-free conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2008), 38(15), 2548-2566

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Thioacetalization Under Solvent-Free
Conditions In a mortar, a mixture of 1,2-ethanedithiol,
1,3-propanedithiol, or ethanethiol (14 mmol), and BTPTB (0.5 mmol 0.3 g)
was added to aldehyde or ketone (10 mmol). The reaction mixture was
ground by pestle at r.t. under solvent-free conditions. After
disappearance of the starting material (monitored by TLC), the mixture
was extracted with diethyl ether (2 x 20 mL) and filtered. The filtrate
was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the resulting crude material
was purified by column chromatography (EtOAc:n-hexane) to afford pure
dithioacetal (Tables I and II). 3e, yield 90%

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical procedure for the oxidation of thiols
benzenethiol (1a) to diphenyl disulfide (2a): A mixture of benzenethiol
(1a) (10 mmol, 1.1 g) and (n-Bu4N)2S2O8 (5.5 mmol, 3.73 g) was ground
thoroughly in a mortar and pestle in for 5 min at room temperature until
the reaction was complete by GC monitoring. The product was extracted
with Et2O (4 x 35 mL). The combined Et2O layers were washed with brine
(315 mL), dried (Na2SO4) and the solvent was evaporated under reduced
pressure to give crude product, which was recrystallized from EtOH to
give pure 2a (1.6 g, 87%) as colorless crystals. 2k, yield 90%. M.P. (°)
or B.P. (°)/Torr: Found 137-198/760, Reported 139/760.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Representative Procedure An oven-dried
three-neck flask was charged with CuI (0.25 mmol, 5.0 mol%), benzenethiol
(6.0 mmol), N-methyl glycine (1.0 mmol, 20 mol%) and KOH (12.5 mmol),
evacuated and backfilled with nitrogen. Aryl iodide (5.0 mmol) and
dioxane (10.0 mL) were added under nitrogen. The reaction mixture was
refluxed for 24 h. The resulting suspension was cooled to r.t. and
filtered through a 2-3 cm pad of silica gel eluting with 100 mL of EtOAc.
The filtrate was concentrated and the residue was purified by
chromatography to afford pure product.14,15 Table 2,Entry 20, yield 90%.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for Table 3. A 4 mL vial
sealed equipped with a magnetic stirrer bar was charged with KOH (56.0
mg, 1.0 mmol) and vinyl bromide (0.6 mmol) in dioxane (0.25 mL); for
vinyl chloride, a 4 mL vial sealed equipped with a magnetic stirrer bar
was charged with KOH (56.0 mg, 1.0 mmol) and vinyl chloride (0.6 mmol) in
NMP (0.5 mL). The aliphatic thiol or aromatic thiol (0.5 mmol) was added
via syringe, and the vial was sealed with a cap containing a PTFE septum
and the reaction vessel was heated at 110 °C in an oil bath. After
stirring at this temperature for 24 h, the heterogeneous mixture was
cooled to room temperature and diluted with ethyl acetate (20 mL). The
resulting solution was directly filtered through a pad of celite then
washed with ethyl acetate (20 mL) and concentrated to give the crude
material which was then purified by column chromatography (SiO2, hexane).
Following the general procedure for Table 3, using
1-(2-bromovinyl)benzene (0.0775 mL, 0.6 mmol) and 1-dodecanethiol (0.1200
mL, 0.5 mmol), then purified by column chromatography (SiO2, hexane).
Dodecyl(styryl)sulfane (5a), white solid (136 mg, 90% yield). M.P.: 26-27
°C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 0.86-0.89 (m, 3 H), 1.26-1.42 (m, 18
H,), 1.63-1.71 (m, 2 H), 2.73-2.79 (m, 2 H), 6.22 (d, J= 11.2 Hz, 1 H),
6.40-6.46 (m, 2 H), 6.71 (d, J= 15.6 Hz, 1 H), 7.14-7.49(m, 5 H).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM stereoselective, alternative preparation shown, trans:cis = 9:1, reaction
in the presence of copper(I) oxide catalyst gave better yield but lower
diastereoselectivity (trans:cis = 5:1), sealed tube used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Experimental Protocol To a stirred 0.2
M solution of 3,4,6-tri-O-acetyl-D-glucal 1 and the acceptor (1 equiv) in
anhydrous solvent (as indicated in Table 2), Amberlyst 15 (80 wt % for 1)
was added in one portion at 25 °C. The mixture was stirred for the
desired time (Table 2) until the complete disappearance of the starting
materials as judged by TLC. The reaction mixture was filtered, and the
resin was washed with acetone. The combined filtrate and washings were
concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was subjected to column
chromatography using petroleum ether-EtOAc as the eluant to afford the
corresponding products. Following the same reaction conditions, O- and
S-nucleophiles gave the corresponding 2,3-unsaturated glycosides as
summarized in Table 2. Glycosides 1b-7b, 9b, 10b, 12b, 14b, and 15b are
known compounds, and their 1H and 13C NMR data matched the reported data
in the cited references (Table 2). 15b, yield 90%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM stereoselective, isomer mix.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Amberlyst 15-catalyzed efficient synthesis of 2,3-unsaturated glycosides
via Ferrier rearrangement for glycal
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Tian, Qiang; Zhu, Xing-Mei; Yang, Jin-Song
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2007), 37(5), 691-701

$DATUM silica-supported

$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Thioacetalization and Transthioacetalization;
General Procedure To a stirred mixture of a carbonyl compound (1 mmol) or
an acetal (1 mmol) and alkyl thiol (2.2 mmol) or ethane dithiol (1.2
mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10 mL), activated NaHSO4·SiO2 (200 mg) was added at r.t.
The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. After completion of
the reaction, the mixture was filtered and the filtrate was concentrated.
The residue was subjected to column chromatography over silica gel and
the column was eluted with EtOAc-hexane (1:4) to afford pure thioacetal.
The spectral and analytical data of the unknown compound are given below.
Compound 2l, yield 90%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Studies on novel synthetic methodologies. Part 39. Simple, mild and
efficient thioacetalization and transthioacetalization of carbonyl
compounds and deprotection of thioacetals: unique role of thiols in the
selectivity of thioacetalization

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Representative procedure for
3-Phenylthiocyclohexan-1-one1 (entry 1, table 1):: Cyclohexenone (0.24 g,
2.5 mmol) in water (5 mL) was treated with thiophenol (0.303 g,2.75 mmol,
1.1 equiv) under magnetic stirring at room temperature (30-35°C) till
complete consumption of the starting material (5 min: TLC, IR). The
reaction mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL). The combined EtOAc
extracts were dried(Na2SO4) and concentrated under reduced pressure to
afford an oil which on passing through a column of silica-gel and elution
with EtOAc-hexane afforded β-phenylthiocyclohexanone (0.464 g, 90%) as
colorless oil, identical (IR, NMR and MS)with an authentic sample.
Colorless oil, yield 90%. 3-Ethylsulfanyl-cyclopentanone (entry 12 table
1): Oily liquid, yield 90%. IR (neat) ν:1745 cm-1; 1H NMR (CDCl3, 300
MHz) δ: 1.29 (t, J =7.3 Hz, 3H), 2.16-2.26 (m, 1H),2.35-2.41 (m, 2H),
2.43-2.51 (m, 2H ), 2.56-2.65 (m, 2H ), 3.44-3.51 (m, 1H); 13C NMR
(CDCl3, 75 MHz) δ: 14.7, 25.2, 29.8, 37.1, 39.9, 45.7, MS (EI): m/z 144
(M+). Anal.Calcd for C7H12OS: C, 58.29; H, 8.39; S, 22.23, Found: C,
58.31; H, 8.40; S, 22.25.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure: A mixture of carbonyl
compound (5 mmol) dithiol (5mmol) or monothiol (10mmol) and InCl3 (0.5
mmol) in dichloromethane (15 ml) was stirred at room temperature for an
appropriate time (table). After completion of the reaction as indicated
by TLC, the reaction mixture was diluted with water (10ml) and extracted
twice with dichloromethane (2 x 10ml). The combined organic layers were
dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, concentrated in vacuo and purified by column
chromatography on silica gel (Merck, 100-200 mesh, ethyl acetate-hexane,
1:9) to give pure dithioacetal. Entry j, yield 90%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Indium(III) chloride catalyzed efficient conversion of carbonyl compounds
to 1,3-dithioacetals

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for Table 2. A 4 mL vial,
sealed and equipped with a magnetic stirrer bar, was charged with KOt-Bu
(112 mg, 1.0 mmol), FeCl3 (0.008 g, 0.05 mmol), and L1 (0.029 g, 0.05
mmol) under a nitrogen atmosphere. The vial was covered with a rubber
septum, and vinyl iodide (1, 0.55 mmol), alkyl or aryl thiol (2, 0.5
mmol), and 1,4-dioxane (0.5 mL) were added by syringe under a nitrogen
atmosphere. The septum was then replaced by a screw cap containing a
Teflon-coated septum, and the reaction vessel was heated at 135 °C. After
stirring at this temperature for 24 h, the heterogeneous mixture was
cooled to room temperature and diluted with ethyl acetate (20 mL). The
resulting solution was filtered through a pad of silica gel and then
washed with ethyl acetate (20 mL) and concentrated to give the crude
material, which was then purified by column chromatography on silica gel
to yield 3. (Cyclohexylidenemethyl)(dodecyl)sulfane 3c (Table 2, Entry
2).12e Following the general procedure for Table 2, using
iodomethylenecyclohexane (0.122 g, 0.55 mmol) and 1-dodecanethiol (0.120
mL, 0.5 mmol), and then purification by column chromatography (SiO2,
hexane) provided 3c as a colorless oil (0.133 g, 90% yield). 1H NMR (400
MHz, CDCl3) δ = 0.88 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 3 H), 1.26-1.51 (m, 24 H), 1.53-1.62
(m, 2 H), 2.13-2.14 (m, 2 H), 2.24- 2.26 (m, 2 H), 2.60 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 2
H), 5.57 (s, 1 H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 14.1, 22.7, 26.4, 27.0,
28.2, 28.6, 29.2, 29.3, 29.5, 29.61, 29.63, 30.1, 30.3, 31.9, 34.0, 36.4,
115.0, 141.9.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Representative Procedure An oven-dried
three-neck flask was charged with CuI (0.25 mmol, 5.0 mol%), benzenethiol
(6.0 mmol), N-methyl glycine (1.0 mmol, 20 mol%) and KOH (12.5 mmol),
evacuated and backfilled with nitrogen. Aryl iodide (5.0 mmol) and
dioxane (10.0 mL) were added under nitrogen. The reaction mixture was
refluxed for 24 h. The resulting suspension was cooled to r.t. and
filtered through a 2-3 cm pad of silica gel eluting with 100 mL of EtOAc.
The filtrate was concentrated and the residue was purified by
chromatography to afford pure product.14,15 Table 2,Entry 22, yield 90%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM Coupling reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM CuI-catalyzed coupling reactions of aryl iodides and bromides with thiols
promoted by amino acid ligands
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Deng, Wei; Zou, Yan; Wang, Ye-Feng; Liu, Lei; Guo, Qing-Xiang
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synlett (2004), (7), 1254-1258

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: (Z)-Dec-1-ene-1,2-diylbis(p-tolylsiilfane)
(3a); Typical Procedure (2)-(1-Bromodec-1-en-2-yl)(p-tolyl)sulfane (1a)
(171 mg, 0.5 mmol) was added to a stirred solution of 4-toluenethiol (2a)
(70 mg, 0.75 mmol), Cu2O (7 mg, 0.05 mmol), DMEDA (8 μL, 0.075 mmol),
Cs2CO3 (326 mg, 1 mmol) in DMF (2 mL) under N2. The resulting mixture was
stirred at 120 °C for 24 h. After being cooled to r.t., the mixture was
diluted with H2O (15 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (3 × 15 mL). The
combined organic layer was dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated. The crude
residue was purified by flash column chromatography (eluent: PE-EtOAc,
50:1). (Z)-Naphthalen-2-yl[1-(octylthio)dec-1-en-2-yl]sulfane (3aa).
Light yellow oil; yield: 199 mg (90%). Reactant: (Z)-2-Bromovinyl sulfide
1e and Aromatic thiol 2k. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 7.81-7.75 (m, 4
H), 7.49-7.41 (m, 3 H), 6.46 (s, 1 H), 2.78 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2 H), 2.27
(t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2 H), 1.74-1.67 (m, 2 H), 1.57-1.51 (m, 2 H), 1.46-1.42
(m, 2 H), 1.31-1.23 (m, 18 H), 0.94-0.87 (m, 6 H). 13C NMR (100 MHz,
CDCl3): δ = 133.7, 132.3, 131.9, 130.4, 128.3, 128.0, 127.7, 127.6,
127.1, 126.3, 125.6, 37.4, 34.1, 31.8, 30.5, 29.3, 29.2, 28.8, 28.6,
28.5, 22.7, 22.6, 14.1. HRMS (TOF): m/z calcd for C28H42S2: 442.2728;
found: 442.2715.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure:
[3R(1'R,4R)]-3-[1-(tert-Butyl-dimethyl-silanyloxy)-ethyl]-4-propylsulfanyl-azetidin-2-one
(5). 23 To a solution of 1-propanethiol (230 μL, 189.3 mg, 2.49 mmol, 1.3
equiv) in acetone (2.3 mL) was added 1 M NaOH (2.6 mL) dropwise. The
mixture was stirred for 15 min at room temperature, and then
[3R(1'R,4R)]-(+)-4-acetoxy-3-[1-(tert-butyldimethylsilyloxy)ethyl]-2-azetidinone
(550.0 mg, 1.91 mmol, 1.0 equiv) in acetone (4.5 mL) was added. After
being stirred overnight at room temperature, the reaction mixture was
concentrated under reduced pressure and extracted with Et2O. The Et2O
solution was washed with water and brine, dried over MgSO4, and
evaporated under reduced pressure. Purification of the residue by flash
column chromatography on silica gel (DCM/MeOH 12:1) yielded 5 (520.3 mg,
90%) as a white solid.
[3R(1'R,4R)]-3-[1-(tert-Butyl-dimethyl-silanyloxy)-ethyl]-4-octylsulfanyl-azetidin-2-one
(7). 23 To a solution of 1-octanethiol (290 μL, 244.3 mg, 1.67 mmol, 1.2
equiv) in acetone (1.6 mL) was added 1 M NaOH (1.8 mL) dropwise. The
mixture was stirred for 15 min at room temperature, and then
[3R(1'R,4R)]-(+)-4-acetoxy-3-[1-(tert-butyldimethylsilyloxy)ethyl]-2-azetidinone
(400 mg, 1.39 mmol, 1.0 equiv) in acetone (1.4 mL) was added. Reaction,
workup, and purification followed the same procedure as described for
compound 5. Compound 7 (468.1 mg, 90%) was isolated as a white solid. 1H
NMR (200 MHz, CDCl3): δ 5.92 (br, 1H, N-H), 4.83 (d, J = 2.3 Hz, 1H,
NH-CHS), 4.25 (dq, J = 6.4 Hz, 3.4 Hz, 1H, CHO), 3.09-3.14 (m, 1H,
O=C-CH), 2.61 (tr, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H, S-CH2), 1.60 (psquint, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H,
S-CH2-CH2), 1.26-1.45 (m, 10H, S-CH2-CH2-C5H10-CH3), 1.23 (d, J = 6.4 Hz,
3H, CH3-CHO), 0.88 (s, 9H, Si-t-butyl), 0.85-0.94 (m, 3H, S-C7H14-CH3),
0.07-0.09 (2s, 6H, Si-CH3).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 6. General procedure for Table 4. A 4 mL vial
sealed equipped with a magnetic stirrer bar was charged with KOH (56.0
mg, 1.0 mmol), Cu2 O (3.5 mg, 0.025 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (0.025
mmol, 10 mol %) and vinyl bromide (0.6 mmol) in dioxane (0.25 mL); for
vinyl chloride, a 4 mL vial sealed equipped with a magnetic stirrer bar
was charged with KOH (56.0 mg, 1.0 mmol), Cu2 O (3.5 mg, 0.025 mmol),
1,10-phenanthroline (0.025 mmol, 10 mol %) and vinyl chloride (0.6 mmol)
in dioxane (0.25 mL). The aliphatic thiol or aromatic thiol (0.5 mmol)
was added via syringe, and the vial was sealed with a cap containing a
PTFE septum and the reaction vessel was heated at 110 °C in an oil bath.
After stirring at this temperature for 24 h, the heterogeneous mixture
was cooled to room temperature and diluted with ethyl acetate (20 mL).
The resulting solution was directly filtered through a pad of celite then
washed with ethyl acetate (20 mL) and concentrated to give the crude
material which was then purified by column chromatography (SiO2, hexane
and CH2Cl2 or ethyl acetate) to 3 in Table 4. Following the general
procedure for Table 4, using bromomethylenecyclohexane (0.080 mL, 0.6
mmol), 1-dodecanethiol (0.120 mL, 0.5 mmol), then purified by column
chromatography (SiO2, hexane). Following the general procedure for Table
2, using bromomethylenecyclohexane (0.080 mL, 0.6 mmol),
2-methylbutane-1-thiol (0.063 mL, 0.5 mmol), then purified by column
chromatography (SiO2, hexane).
(Cyclohexylidenemethyl)(2-methylbutyl)sulfane (3c), colorless oil (89 mg,
90% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz,CDCl3): δ = 0.89 (t, J= 7.2 Hz, 3 H), 0.97
(d, J= 6.8 Hz, 3 H), 1.16-1.27 (m, 1 H), 1.44-1.62 (m, 8 H), 2.12-2.14
(m, 2 H), 2.25-2.27 (m, 2 H), 2.45 (dd, J= 5.6, 12.8 Hz, 1 H), 2.62 (dd,
J= 5.6, 12.8 Hz, 1 H), 5.55 (s, 1 H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 11.3,
18.6, 26.4, 27.0, 28.2, 28.5, 30.3, 35.2, 36.4, 41.3, 115.6, 141.5;
HREI-MS calcd. for C12 H22 S: 198.1442, Found: 198.1448.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure In a typical experiment, a
mixture of 3,4,6-tri-O-acetyl-D-glucal (5 mmol) P-chlorothiophenol (5
mmol) and scandium triflate (5% w/w of glucal) in dichloromethane (15mL)
was stirred at room temperature for 3h. After complete conversion, as
indicated by TLC, the reaction mixture was diluted with water (10 mL) and
extracted twice with dichloromethane (2 x 10mL). The combined organic
layers were dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated in vacuo and
purified by column chromatography on silica gel (Merck, 100-200 mesh,
ethyl acetate-hexane, 2:8) to afford pure thioglycoside in 90% yield. The
aqueous layer was concentrated in vacuo to recover the catalyst. Table
1., Entry o, yield 90%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM stereoselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Scandium triflate catalyzed thioglycosidation of glycals: A facile
synthesis of 2,3-unsaturated thioglycopyranosides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Yadav, J. S.; Reddy, B. V. S.; Geetha, V.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2003), 33(5), 717-722

$DATUM 67-64-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Dual ROP/RAFT initiator (1) The dual ROP/RAFT initiator was prepared as
previously reported.4 Briefly; dodecanethiol (6.46 g, 31.9 mmol),
potassium phosphate (7.45 g, 35.1 mmol) and carbon disulphide (5.95 mL,
99.0 mmol) were added to acetone (600 mL), and the reaction stirred at
ambient temperature. After 2 h, 4-(chloromethyl)benzyl alcohol (5 g, 31.9
mmol) was added, and the reaction stirred at ambient temperature for 23
h. The solvent was removed in vacuo, and the resultant solid was
re-dissolved in dichloromethane (200 mL). The organic layer washed with
HCl (1M, 150 mLx2), water (150 mLx3), brine (150 mL) and then dried
(MgSO4). The solvent was removed in vacuo to give the crude product as a
yellow solid. Washing with hexanes gave the product as a yellow solid
(11.45 g, 90%). This product was dried under a P2O5 atmosphere in a
desiccator for 2 days and stored under a N2 atmosphere. 1, (11.45 g, 90%)
1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.30-7.20 (4H, m, H8 & H9), 4.68 (2H, s, H11),
4.61 (2H, s, H6), 3.37 (2H, t J = 7.5 Hz, H4), 1.77-1.58 (3H, m, H3 &
H12), 1.46-1.20 (18H, m, H2), 0.88 (3H, t J = 7.0 Hz, H1); 13C NMR (125
MHz, CDCl3) δ 223.7 (C5), 140.4 (C7), 134.6 (C10), 129.5 (C8), 127.3
(C9), 65.0 (C11), 41.0 (C6), 37.1 (C4), 32-22 (C2-3), 14.1 (C1); FTIR
(neat) νmax / cm-1 3492-3293 (O-H), 1583 (aromatic), 1469 (aromatic);
HR-MS (MaXis) m/z found 421.1669, calc. 421.1664 (M+Na, 100 %).

$DATUM (Dodecylsulfanyl)({[4-(hydroxymethyl)phenyl]methyl}sulfanyl)methanethione
(1). This was prepared by a similar procedure to that previously
reported.1 Briefly; dodecanethiol (6.46 g, 31.9 mmol), potassium
phosphate (7.45 g, 35.1 mmol) and carbon disulphide (5.95 ml, 99.0 mmol)
were added to acetone (600 ml) and the reaction stirred at ambient
temperature. After 2h, 4-(chloromethyl)benzyl alcohol (5 g, 31.9 mmol)
was added and the reaction stirred at ambient temperature for 23 h. The
solvent was removed in vacuo. and the resultant solid re-dissolved in
dichloromethane (200 ml) and the organic layer washed with HCl (1M, 150
ml×2), water (150 ml×3), brine (150 ml) and dried (MgSO4). The solvent
was removed in vacuo. to give the crude product as a yellow solid.
Washing with hexanes. The product as a yellow solid (11.45 g, 90%). 1H
NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ7.30-7.20 (4H, m, H8 & H9), 4.68 (1H, s, H11), 4.61
(1H, s, H6), 3.37 (2H, t, J = 7.5 Hz, H4), 1.77-1.58 (3H, m, H3 & H12),
1.46-1.20 (18H, m, H2), 0.88 (3H, t, J = 7.0 Hz, H1); 13C NMR (125 MHz,
CDCl3) δ223.7 (C5), 140.4 (C7), 134.6 (C10), 129.5 (C8), 127.3 (C9), 65.0
(C11), 41.0 (C6), 37.1 (C4), 32-22 (C2-3), 14.1 (C1); FTIR (neat)
ν3492-3293 cm-1 (O-H), 1583 cm-1 (aromatic), 1469 cm-1 (aromatic); HR-MS
(MaXis) m/z found 421.1669, calc. 421.1664 (M+Na, 100 %).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure In a typical experiment, a
mixture of 3,4,6-tri-O-acetyl-D-glucal (5 mmol) P-chlorothiophenol (5
mmol) and scandium triflate (5% w/w of glucal) in dichloromethane (15mL)
was stirred at room temperature for 3h. After complete conversion, as
indicated by TLC, the reaction mixture was diluted with water (10 mL) and
extracted twice with dichloromethane (2 x 10mL). The combined organic
layers were dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated in vacuo and
purified by column chromatography on silica gel (Merck, 100-200 mesh,
ethyl acetate-hexane, 2:8) to afford pure thioglycoside in 90% yield. The
aqueous layer was concentrated in vacuo to recover the catalyst. Table
1., Entry k, yield 90%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM stereoselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Scandium triflate catalyzed thioglycosidation of glycals: A facile
synthesis of 2,3-unsaturated thioglycopyranosides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Yadav, J. S.; Reddy, B. V. S.; Geetha, V.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2003), 33(5), 717-722

$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Etherification and Thioetherification of
p-Hydroxybenzyl Alcohols: General Procedure p-Hydroxybenzyl alcohol (1
mmol) and reacting alcohol (or thiol) (3 mmol) was taken in CH2Cl2 (5
mL). NaHSO4•SiO2 (100 mg) was added. The catalyst was prepared from the
readily available ingredients, NaHSO4 and silica gel (finer than 200
mesh), by following the reported method.[5] The reaction mixture was
stirred at room temperature and the reaction was monitored by thin layer
chromatography (TLC). After completion, the mixture was filtered, the
filtrate was concentrated, and the residue was subjected to column
chromatography over silica gel to obtain pure ether (or thioether).
bis-(4-Hydroxybenzyl)-ether (4%-5%) was also obtained while preparing an
ether. Table 2. Entry 23, yield 90%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry, green chemistry-catalyst, solid-supported catalyst,
silica gel used, other product detected
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Studies on novel synthetic methodologies. Part 31. Silica-supported
sodium hydrogen sulfate-catalyzed facile transformation of
p-hydroxybenzyl alcohols to p-hydroxybenzyl ethers and thioethers
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Ramu, R.; Ravindra Nath, N.; Reddy, M. R.; Das, Biswanath
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthetic Communications (2004), 34(17), 3135-3145

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Etherification and Thioetherification of
p-Hydroxybenzyl Alcohols: General Procedure p-Hydroxybenzyl alcohol (1
mmol) and reacting alcohol (or thiol) (3 mmol) was taken in CH2Cl2 (5
mL). NaHSO4•SiO2 (100 mg) was added. The catalyst was prepared from the
readily available ingredients, NaHSO4 and silica gel (finer than 200
mesh), by following the reported method.[5] The reaction mixture was
stirred at room temperature and the reaction was monitored by thin layer
chromatography (TLC). After completion, the mixture was filtered, the
filtrate was concentrated, and the residue was subjected to column
chromatography over silica gel to obtain pure ether (or thioether).
bis-(4-Hydroxybenzyl)-ether (4%-5%) was also obtained while preparing an
ether. 4-Hydroxybenzyl n-Dodecyl Thioether (17B), yield 90% 1H NMR (200
MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.14 (2H, d, J= 8.0Hz), 6.70 (2H, d, J= 8.0Hz), 4.62 (1H,
s), 3.58 (2H, s), 2.32 (2H, t, J= 7.0 Hz), 1.62-1.44 (2H, m), 1.40- 1.12
(18H, m), 0.84 (3H, t, J= 7.0 Hz). EI-MS: m/z = 308 (M+). Anal. Calcd.
for C19H32OS: C, 74.02; H, 10.38. Found: C, 74.00; H, 10.14.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry, green chemistry-catalyst, solid-supported catalyst,
silica gel used, other product detected
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

sodium hydrogen sulfate-catalyzed facile transformation of
p-hydroxybenzyl alcohols to p-hydroxybenzyl ethers and thioethers
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Cesium-Mediated Addition of Thiol to Alkyne: A
Typical Procedure. The reaction of dodecanethiol with phenylacetylene is
representative (Table 1, entry 10). Cesium carbonate (0.016 g, 0.050
mmol) was placed in a 20-mL reaction flask under argon. Dimethyl
sulfoxide (3.0 mL) and dodecanethiol (0.12 g, 0.60 mmol) were added at
room tem-perature. After the mixture was stirred for 15 min, 2,2,6,6-
tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl (0.016 g, 0.10 mmol) was added. The whole
mixture was stirred for 15 min. Finally, phenylacetylene (0.051 g, 0.50
mmol) was added and the resulting mixture was stirred for 4 h. Water (10
mL) was added, and the product was extracted with hexane/ethyl acetate
(40:1, 3 x 10 mL). The combined organic layer was dried over sodium
sulfate and concentrated under reduced pressure. Silica gel column
purification of the crude oil provided 0.13 g of dodecyl styryl sulfide
(1a, 0.43 mmol, E/Z ) 7:93) in 86% yield.
4-[(Z)-2-Dodecylthioethenyl]anisole (1b): IR (neat) 2924, 2853, 1607,
1508, 1466, 1304, 1254, 1175, 1038, 831, 534 cm-1; 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ 0.88
(t, J = 6.8 Hz, 3H), 1.18-1.45 (m, 18H), 1.68 (t, J = 7.5, 7.5 Hz, 2H),
2.77 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 3.81 (s, 3H), 6.11 (d, J = 11.0 Hz, 1H), 6.38
(d, J = 11.0 Hz, 1H), 6.89 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2H), 7.44 (d, J = 9.0 Hz, 2H);
13C NMR (CDCl3) δ 14.1, 22.7, 28.6, 29.2, 29.3, 29.5, 29.57, 29.61,
29.63, 30.2, 31.9, 35.8, 55.2, 113.7, 124.8, 125.1, 129.9, 129.7, 158.1.
Found: C, 75.33; H, 10.27. Calcd for C21H34OS: C, 75.39; H, 10.24.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure. To a solution of sodium
carbonate in ethanol were slowly added required amounts of
2,3-dichloro-1,4-naphthoquinone (I) and thiol, the mixture was stirred
for 24 h without heating, the color of the solution quickly changed. On
completion of the reaction (TLC monitoring) 30 ml of chloroform was
added, the organic layer was separated, washed with water (4 × 30 ml),
dried with Na2SO4, evaporated in a vacuum, the residue was treated with
dichloromethane in a Soxhlet apparatus. On evaporation of the solvent the
compounds were isolated from the residue by column chromatography on
silica gel. 2,3-Bis(hexadecylsulfanyl)-1,4-naphthoquinone (III) was
obtained from 1 g (4.4 mmol) of dichloride I and 2.27 g (8.8 mmol) of
hexadecanethiol. Yield 2.66 g (90%). Light red crystals. mp 84-86°C, Rf
0.28 (CCl4). IR spectrum (KBr), ν, cm-1: 2918, 2851 (C-H), 1656 (C=O),
1590 (C=C). 1H NMR spectrum, δ, ppm: 0.88 t (6H, CH3, J 7.08 Hz),
1.24-1.66 m (56H, CH2), 3.26 t (4H, SCH2, J 7.32 Hz), 7.67 d.d (2Harom,
AA'ΒΒ', J 8.79 Hz), 8.04 d.d (2Harom, AA'ΒΒ', J 8.78 Hz). 13C NMR
spectrum, δ, ppm: 14.0 (CH3), 22.91, 28.96, 29.40, 29.60, 29.70, 29.80,
29.90, 30.0, 30.70, 32.10, 35.20 (CH2), 127.0, 133.8, 133.6, 148.0
(Cnaphth), 179.0 (C=O). Mass spectrum, m/z (Irel, %): 671.4 (100) [M]+.
Found, %: C 75.02; H 10.51; S 9.08. C42H70O2S2. Calculated, %: C 75.16; H
10.51; S 9.55. M 671.15.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

derivatives

$DATUM Sayil, C.; Ibis, C.

$DATUM Russian Journal of Organic Chemistry (2010), 46(2), 209-215

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM (E)-S-Ethyl 6-(2-benzoylcyclopropyl)-2,5,5-trimethylhex-2-enethioate: A
mixture of (E)-ethyl 6-(2-benzoylcyclopropyl)-2,5,5-trimethylhex-2-enoate
(0.431 g, 1.31 mmol) in acetone (13 mL) was refluxed with LiOH (1 M, 18
mL) for 1 h. Upon consumption of starting material, the reaction mixture
was cooled to room temperature. The reaction mixture was washed with
ether (5 mL) and acidified with HCl (1 M) (pH<1). The aqueous layer was
extracted with ether (10 mL × 3), and the combined organic layers were
dried over MgSO4 and concentrated in vacuo. To this residue was added
CH2Cl2 (10 mL), ethanethiol (0.16 g, 2.62 mmol), DMAP (18.3 mg, 0.15
mmoL), and N,N'-dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (0.33 g, 1.5 mmoL) at 0 °C. Upon
addition, the reaction warmed to room temperature and stirred for an
additional 11 h. The reaction mixture was then filtered though silica gel
with ether and concentrated in vacuo. The crude residue was dissolved in
50 mL of ether, washed with 1N HCl, water, and brine. The organic layer
was dried over MgSO4 and concentrated in vacuo. Purification by
flash-column chromatography (20:1 hexanes/EtOAc) afforded 0.4039 g (1.17
mmol, 90% yield) of the title compound as an oil. IR(neat) 2960, 2930,
2871, 1664, 1620, 1598, 1581, 1449, 1403, 1366, 1222, 1022 cm-1. 1H NMR:
(500.2 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.01-7.97 (m, 2H), 7.56 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 1H), 7.47
(t, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H), 6.79 (tq, J = 7.6, 1.5 Hz, 1H), 2.92 (q, J = 7.3 Hz,
2H), 2.44 (dt, J = 8.5, 4.5 Hz, 1H), 2.17 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 2H), 1.83 (q, J
= 1.0 Hz, 3H), 1.64-1.57 (m, 1H), 1.55-1.49 (m, 2H), 1.32 (dd, J = 14.3,
7.3 Hz, 1H), 1.28 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H), 1.00 (d, J = 1.2 Hz, 6H), 0.93
(ddd, J = 7.8, 6.4, 3.4 Hz, 1H); 13C NMR: (125.8 MHz, CDCl3) δ 200.0,
193.9, 137.9, 137.4, 137.3, 132.7, 128.5, 128.0, 45.7, 40.8, 35.4, 27.21,
27.17, 25.1, 23.3, 22.8, 19.5, 14.7, 12.6. HRMS (ESI) calculated for
[C21H28O2SNa]+(M+Na+) requires m/z 367.1703, found m/z 367.1701.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

Photocatalysis
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 2'-Deoxy-2'-(t-butyldithio)uridine.
2'-Deoxy-2'-(2-nitrophenyldithio)-uridine5d (94 mg, 0.243 mmol) was
dissolved in 10% MeOH/CHCl3 (12.5 mL). In a separate flask,
2-methyl-2-propanethiol (164 μL, 1.46 mmol), triethylamine (375 μL), and
methanol (3.8 mL) were combined. The solution was transferred to the
reaction flask and stirred for 3 h at room temperature. The reaction was
concentrated, and the residue was purified by column chromatography
(0-10% MeOH in CHCl3) to give 2'-deoxy-2'-(tert-butyldithio)uridine as a
white solid (90% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ 7.96 (d, 1H, J = 8.1
Hz), 5.85 (d, 1H, J = 9.8 Hz), 5.77 (d, 1H, J = 8.1 Hz), 4.26 (d, 1H, J =
4.6 Hz), 4.03 (m, 1H), 3.78 (m, 2H), 3.63 (q, 1H), 1.35 (s, 9H). HRMS
(FAB+): calculated for C13H21N2O5S2 (MH+) 349.0879; found 349.0878.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DATUM 2-Alkylthio(arylthio)-4-nitro-and -4,6-dinitrobenzamides 2a-h and
9a,c,d,f (general procedure). A corresponding thiol (2.2 mmol) and Na2CO3
(0.24 g, 2.2 mmol) were added successively to a solution of amide la,b or
8a,c,d,f (2 mmol) in DMF (8 mL).The reaction mixture was stirred at 20 °C
for 5-8 h (in the case of thiophenol, the reaction was carried out in an
atmosphere of nitrogen) until the starting amide was completely consumed
(TLC) and then acidified with 0.05 M HCl (15 mL).The precipitate that
formed was filtered off, washed with water (2x5 mL), dried in air, and
recrystallized from PriOH. Compound: 2a. M.p.: 193-197°C.Molecular
formula: C9H10N7O3S; 1H NMR δ J/Hz: 1.31 (t, 3 H, CH2CH3, J = 5.0); 3.02
(q, 2 H, CH2CH3, J = 8.0); 7.62 (d, 1H, H(6), J = 6.0); 7.63,7.96 (both
s, 1H each, NB); 8.00 (d, 1H, H(5), J = 6.0); 8.08 (s, 1H, H(3)).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Nitro derivatives of cyclic sulfoximides of the 1,2-benzoisothiazole
series

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM S-Ethyl (2R,3S)-2-ethyl-3-((triethylsilyl)oxy)pent-4-enethioate 192: To a
solution of alcohol 186 (517 mg, 1.7 mmol) in DMF (26 mL) was added
imidazole (696 mg, 10.2 mmol) and TESCl (771 microL, 5.1 mmol) and the
resulting solution stirred for 5 minutes. The reaction mixture was
diluted with Et2O and the organic layer washed with brine four times,
dried (MgSO4), filtered and concentrated under reduced pressure. The
residue was used without further purification. To a solution of ethane
thiol (341 microL, 4.6 mmol) in THF (24 mL) at 0 degC was added n-BuLi
(3.41 mL, 4.4 mmol, 1.3 M in hexanes) and the resulting solution stirred
at 0 degC for 10 minutes. This solution was added via cannula addition to
the crude residue in THF (24 mL) at 0 degC and the resulting solution
stirred at 0 degC for 2 hr. The reaction mixture was quenched with sat.
aq. NH4Cl and extracted with EtOAc. The combined organic layers were
washed with brine and dried (MgSO4), filtered and concentrated under
reduced pressure. The residue was purified by flash column chromatography
on silica using 15:1 petrol:Et2O as the eluent to give thioester 192 (418
mg, 90 % from 186) as a colourless oil. [alpha 25 D] = -11 deg (c = 0.53
in CHCl3).

$DATUM Bridgwood, B. K.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM (2009), (20121004), No pp.

$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Compound 16 Compound 4 (400.0 mg, 0.26 mmol),
Cs2CO3 (0.34 g, 1.06 mmol, 4 equiv), and dry DMF (5.0 mL) were treated
with 1-hexanethiol (0.52 mL, 3.73 mmol, 14 equiv) at room temperature for
15 hours. Upon completion of the reaction as observed by TLC (5% methanol
in dichloromethane), the reaction mixture was diluted with EtOAc (50 mL),
and the organic layer was washed twice with brine and concentrated under
reduced pressure. Compound 17 Compound 17 was prepared in a manner
similar to that used to prepare 16. Compound 4 (300.0 mg, 0.2 mmol),
Cs2CO3 (0.24 g, 0.8 mmol), dry DMF (5.0 mL), and 1-decanethiol (0.59 mL,
2.80 mmol) were allowed to react at room temperature for 15 hours. Upon
completion of the reaction as observed by TLC (5% methanol in
dichloromethane), purification by flash column chromatography (SiO2, 3%
methanol in dichloromethane). 17 (250 mg, 90%) as a white solid. LRMS
(ESI) m/z calculated for C68H119N5O20S2 [M-H]- 1388.79, found
1388.73.1H-NMR (500 MHz, CD3OD) δ 7.31 (s, 2H, TIBS), 5.17 (bs, 1H,

$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Etherification and Thioetherification of
p-Hydroxybenzyl Alcohols: General Procedure p-Hydroxybenzyl alcohol (1
mmol) and reacting alcohol (or thiol) (3 mmol) was taken in CH2Cl2 (5
mL). NaHSO4•SiO2 (100 mg) was added. The catalyst was prepared from the
readily available ingredients, NaHSO4 and silica gel (finer than 200
mesh), by following the reported method.[5] The reaction mixture was
stirred at room temperature and the reaction was monitored by thin layer
chromatography (TLC). After completion, the mixture was filtered, the
filtrate was concentrated, and the residue was subjected to column
chromatography over silica gel to obtain pure ether (or thioether).
bis-(4-Hydroxybenzyl)-ether (4%-5%) was also obtained while preparing an
ether. 4-Hydroxybenzyl n-Decyl Thioether (16B), yield 90% 1H NMR (200MHz,
CDCl3): δ 7.12 (2H, d, J= 8.0Hz), 6.68 (2H, d, J= 8.0 Hz), 4.55 (1H, s),
3.59 (2H, s), 2.31 (2H, t, J= 7.0 Hz), 1.58-1.42 (2H, m), 1.10-1.18 (14H,
m), 0.83 (3H, t, J= 7.0Hz). EI-MS: m/z = 280 (M+). Anal. Calcd. for
C17H28OS: C, 72.85; H, 10.00; O, 5.71; S, 11.42. Found: C, 72.45; H,
9.54; 0, 5.68; S, 11.32.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry, green chemistry-catalyst, solid-supported catalyst,
silica gel used, other product detected
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

sodium hydrogen sulfate-catalyzed facile transformation of
p-hydroxybenzyl alcohols to p-hydroxybenzyl ethers and thioethers

$DATUM 1-t-Butylsulfanyl-2-(2,4-difluoro-phenyl)-3-[1,2,4]triazol-1-yl-propan-2-ol
(175): The solvents required for this reaction were deoxygenated prior to
use by the rapid passage of nitrogen through the solvent for not less
than 30 min. A solution of
1-[2-(2,4-difluoro-phenyl)-oxiranylmethyl]-1H-[1,2,4]triazole 176 (0.770
g, 3.2 mmol) in t-BuOH (15 cm**3) was mixed with a 0.5 N aqueous NaOH
solution (15 cm**3) in a preheated (70 degC) oil bath. The reaction
mixture was stirred vigorously as a dropwise addition of a solution of
t-butyl thiol (0.47 cm**3, 4.2 mmol) in t-BuOH (4 cm**3) was conducted
over a period of 30 min. During this time the oil bath temperature rose
to 78 degC. Stirring was continued for 20 min after the dropwise addition
was complete. The reaction mixture was then cooled to room temperature
and neutralized with a saturated aqueous NH4Cl solution. Sufficient
distilled water was then added to clarify the aqueous phase, and the
phases were then separated. The aqueous phase was extracted with
dichloromethane (5 x 30 cm**3, and the combined organic phases were
washed with saturated aqueous NH4Cl (50 cm**3), dried over MgSO4,
concentrated to afford the title compound 175 as a white solid (0.940 g,
90 %), Rf = 0.2 (diethyl ether); mp 98 degC.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical procedure of the Lewis acid-catalyzed
thiolysis at pH 4.0 In a flask thermostated at 30 °C, thiol (1.05 mmol)
and 1.0 mL of a 0.1 M aqueous solution of the Lewis acid (0.1 mmol) were
added to 0.7 mL of water. By addition of little amounts of NaOH 0.5 M the
pH was brought to the desiderated value. The α,β-epoxy acid (1.0 mmol)
was then added under stirring and the pH was kept constant at pH 4.0 by
adding a 5 M NaOH solution. When the reaction was complete, the resulting
mixture was cooled at 0 °C , acidified to pH 1.0 by adding some drops of
10% aqueous H2SO4 and extracted with EtOAc (3 x 2 mL). The combined
organic layers were dried over Na2SO4 and evaporated under reduced
pressure to give the corresponding β-hydroxy sulfides that were purified
by recristallization or by column chromatography.
Rel(2S,3R)-3-(allylthio)-2-hydroxy-3-phenylpropanoic acid (5b) oil;
chromatography on silica gel, eluent: 70/28/2-petroleum ether/EtOAc/AcOH;
90% yield; 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz) δ = 2.95 (dd, J = 8.0, 13.9 Hz, 1H),
3.10-3.15 (m, 1H), 4.26 (d, J = 3.6 Hz, 1H), 4.61 (d, J = 3.6 Hz, 1H),
5.00-5.14 (m, 2H), 5.74-5.78 (m, 1H), 7.27-7.31 (m, 3H), 7.33-7.38 (m,
2H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100.6 MHz) δ = 34.4, 51.2, 73.0, 117.9, 128.1,
128.4, 129.1, 133.6, 136.2; GC-EIMS on methylester derivative:
decomposition; anal. calcd. for C12H14O3S (238,3): C 60.48; H 5.92;
found: C 60.45; H 5.90.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Synthesis of (α-Alkoxybenzyl)pyrrole (5).
General Procedure. To a solution of the corresponding alcohol (4.5 mmol)
in THF (40 mL) was added NaH (0.10 g, 4.1 mmol). After the mixture was
refluxed for 1.5 h, crude 9 (0.60 g, 1.51 mmol) was added, and the
mixture was refluxed for another 3 h. After the solvent was evaporated,
the residue was dissolved in dichloromethane (50 mL), washed with water
(3 x 25 mL) and brine, dried over anhydrous magnesium sulfate, and then
concentrated. The crude was purified by silica gel using petroleum
ether/ethyl acetate (10:1) as the eluent to give 5 as a white solid.
Synthesis of (α-(Alkylsulfanyl)benzyl)pyrroles 7 and Benzylpyrrole
α-Oxime Ethers 8. The synthetic procedures were according to that of 5
using compound 9 and 1.5−2 equiv of the corresponding alkanethiol or
oxime as the starting material. Data for
4-bromo-2-(α-(ethylthio)-4-chlorobenzyl)-5-(trifluoromethyl)-
1H-pyrrole-3-carbonitrile (7a): yield 90%; pale yellow solid. Mp 46−48
°C; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 9.50 (s, 1H), 7.34 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H),
7.25 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 5.32 (s, 1H), 2.64−2.28 (m, 2H), 1.28 (t, J =
7.6 Hz, 3H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 140.4, 134.5, 133.6, 128.5,
127.9, (122.4, 119.8, 117.1, 114.4), (118.7, 118.3, 117.9, 117.5), 111.4,
100.3, 100.3, 97.1, 44.0, 25.9, 13.2; HRMS (ESI) m/z calcd for
C15H10BrClF3N2S (M− H)− 420.9394, found 420.9395.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM S-Ethyl (2E)-4-methylpent-2-enethioate (2.28): Procedure (A) for the
synthesis of alpha,beta-unsaturated thioesters from carboxylic acids:
Dicyclohexyl carbodiimide (DCC) (1.1 g, 5.3 mmol) was added to a stirred
solution of the corresponding alpha,beta-unsaturated carboxylic acid (5.0
mmol), ethanethiol (481 microL, 6.5 mmol) and DMAP (61 mg, 0.5 mmol) in
CH2Cl2 (25 mL) at 0 degC. The reaction mixture was allowed to warm to
room temperature overnight. The mixture was filtered over Celite and the
filter cake was washed with CH2Cl2. The filtrate was washed with a
saturated aqueous NaHCO3 solution, H2O, brine, dried (MgSO4) and the
solvent evaporated in vacuo. Flash chromatography of the residue over
silica gel gave the corresponding thioester. Thioester 2.28 was obtained
from 4-methylpent-2-enoic acid following procedure A. Flash
chromatography of the residue using n-pentane/Et2O 60:1 gave 2.28 as a
colourless oil (90 % yield).

$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 1.1. Procedure for the synthesis of α,β-unsaturated thioesters from
carboxylic acids1 Dicyclohexyl carbodiimide (DCC) (1.09 g, 5.3 mmol) was
added at 0 °C to a solution of the corresponding α,β-unsaturated
carboxylic acid (5.0 mmol), ethanethiol (481 μL, 6.5 mmol) and 4-
(dimethylamino)pyridine (DMAP) (61 mg, 0.5 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (25 mL) and
the resulting mixture was allowed to slowly warm to rt overnight. The
mixture was then filtered through Celite® and the filter cake was washed
with CH2Cl2. The filtrate was washed with a saturated aqueous NaHCO3
solution, H2O and brine, then dried over MgSO4, concentrated under
reduced pressure and the crude product purified by flash chromatography
to give the corresponding thioester. S-Ethyl
(2E)-4-methylpent-2-enethioate (3b): Thioester 3b was obtained from
4-methylpent-2-enoic acid following the general Procedure 1.1, after
purification by flash chromatography (pentane/Et2O 60:1), as a colorless
oil (90% yield). 1H-NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 1.04 (d, J = 6.9 Hz, 6H), 1.24
(t, J = 7.3 Hz, 3H), 2.39 (m, 1H), 2.90 (q, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H), 6.01 (d, J =
15.7 Hz, 1H), 6.83 (dd, J = 6.6 Hz, J = 15.7 Hz, 1H). 13C-NMR (100.59
MHz, CDCl3) δ 14.7, 21.1, 22.9, 30.8, 125.9, 151.1, 190.3. LRMS (CI) m/z:
158 (M+), 97 (100), 41; HRMS calcd for C8H14OS (M+): 158.0765; found:
158.0767.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Highly Versatile Enantioselective Conjugate Addition of Grignard Reagents
to α,β-Unsaturated Thioesters
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Ruiz, Beatriz Macia; Geurts, Koen; Fernandez-Ibanez, M. Angeles; ter
Horst, Bjorn; Minnaard, Adriaan J.; Feringa, Ben L.

$DATUM Organic Letters (2007), 9(24), 5123-5126

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Synthesis of 6-(bis(ethylthio)methyl)-2-dimethylaminonaphthalene (DTA 1).
Compound 5 (50 mg, 0.25 mmol) and ethanethiol (45 μL, 0.625 mmol) was
dissolved in dry CH2Cl2 (5 mL) and cooled to 0°C under argon. BF3•Et2O
(79 μL, 0.75 mmol) was added at 0°C to the reaction mass and stirred at
the same temperature for 2 h and then allowed it to attain to room
temperature (24-26°C). Aldehyde consumption was monitored by tlc and then
quenched the reaction mass with aqueous NaHCO3 (pH 8-9). CH2Cl2 layer
separated and extracted the aqueous layer with CH2Cl2, and then purified
by silica gel column chromatography (Ethyl acetate/Hexane (2/98) as
eluent). DTA 1, yield 69 mg, 90%. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.62 (3H,
m), 7.49 (1H , dd, J = 9.0, Hz), 7.14 (1H, d, J = 9.0 Hz), 6.90 (1H, d, J
= 3.0 Hz), 5.05 (1H, s), 3.05 (6H, s), 2.49 (4H, m), 1.19 (6H, t); 13C
NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3) δ 148.98, 134.69, 133.54, 128.82, 127.01, 126.24,
126.17, 126.12, 116.71, 106.48, 52.73, 40.95, 26.34, 14.45. HRMS (m/z):
calcd for C17H23NS2: 305.13; found 305.1272.

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 99-61-6
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 181940-67-0
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1360830-73-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-614-CAS-28715692
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 90
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-63-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 108-88-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Procedure for the Synthesis of
3-Isopropenyl-6-methyl-2-phenyltetrahydrothiopyran (3a, Table 1).
6-Methyl-hept-5-ene-2-thiol (86 mg, 0.6 mmol) in 2 mL of toluene was
added dropwise to a stirring mixture of benzaldehyde (53 mg, 0.5 mmol),
boron trifluoride etherate (63 μL, 0.5 mmol), and toluene (2 mL) at 0°C.
The stirring was continued at the same temperature for 30 min, and then
the mixture was poured into saturated NaHCO3 (5 mL). The reaction mixture
was extracted with ethyl acetate and then washed with brine and water.
The organic layers were collected, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and
concentrated. Then the resultant crude residue was purified by column
chromatography over silica gel (petroleum ether/ EtOAc 98:2).
Tetrahydro-6-methyl-2-phenyl-2-(3-nitrophenyl)(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2H-thiopyran
(3b): pale yellow crystalline solid; Yield (125 mg, 90%). mp 100-102°C.
1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 1.22 (d, J= 6.8 Hz, 3 H), 1.49 (s, 3 H),
1.52-1.65 (m, 2 H), 1.95-2.05 (m, 1 H), 2.09-2.19 (m, 1 H), 2.63 (dt, J=
10.4 and 2.8 Hz, 1 H), 2.97-3.06 (m, 1 H), 3.99 (d, J= 11.2 Hz, 1 H),
4.57-4.61 (m, 2 H), 7.44 (t, J= 8.0 Hz, 1 H), 7.61 (d, J= 7.6 Hz, 1 H),
8.07 (d, J= 7.2 Hz, 1 H), 8.16 (s, 1 H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 20.3,
21.1, 33.4, 37.0, 40.0, 50.1, 51.5, 113.1, 122.4, 123.4, 129.3, 134.6,
143.1, 146.6, 148.3; IR (KBr, neat) 2963, 2924, 1639, 1529, 1448, 1350,
1267, 1098, 891 cm-1; HRMS (APCI) calcd for C15H19NO2S (M + H)+ requires
278.1209, found 278.1223.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Reactions of tetrachlorophthalonitrile with
thiols (general procedure). Tetrachlorophthalonitrile (I), 1.33 g, and a
required amount (0.005, 0.010, 0.015, or 0.020 mol) of the corresponding
thiol were dispersed in 20 ml of DMF, and an equimolar amount of
triethylamine (with respect to the thiol) was added dropwise under
stirring at room temperature. The mixture gradually turned brown, and a
white solid separated. The mixture was stirred for 1 h, poured into 5%
hydrochloric acid, and extracted with benzene (or the precipitate was
filtered off and dissolved in benzene), and the products were separated
by column chromatography on silica gel using benzene as eluent or were
purified by recrystallization. Compound IX. Yield: 90%. mp, °C: 141-142
(From ethanol), IR spectra: (2228, νCN cm-1). Found, %, C: 59.80, 59.91,
H: 7.46, 7.57, N: 5.89, 5.93, S: 26.67, 26.74, Formula: C24H36N2S4.
Calculated, %, C: 59.95, H: 7.55, N: 5.83, S: 26.68, M+: 480.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Ruthenium-Catalyzed Propargylic Substitution
Reaction of Propargylic Alcohols Bearing Internal Alkyne Group with
Thiols. A typical experimental procedure for the reaction of
1,3-diphenyl-2-propyn-1-ol (2a) with nBuSH catalyzed
by[Cp*RuCl(μ2-SMe)2RuCp*(OH2)]OTf (1e) is described below. In a 20 mL
flask was placed 1e (12.2 mg, 0.015 mmol) under N2. Anhydrous ClCH2CH2Cl
(8 mL) was added, and then the mixture was magnetically stirred at room
temperature. After the addition of 2a (64.1 mg, 0.30 mmol) and nBuSH (135
mg, 1.50 mmol), the reaction flask was kept at 60 °C for 1 h. The solvent
was concentrated under reduced pressure by an aspirator, and then the
residue was purified by TLC (SiO2) with EtOAc-hexane (1/9) to give butyl
1,3-diphenyl-2-propynyl sulfide (3aa) as a pale yellow oil (78.0 mg,
0.278 mmol, 92% yield). 3-Methylbutyl 1-phenyl-2-heptynyl sulfide (3db):
Yield 90%. A pale yellow oil. 1H NMR δ 0.87 (d, 3H, J = 6.8 Hz), 0.87 (d,
3H, J = 6.8 Hz), 0.91 (t, 3H, J = 7.0 Hz), 1.47 (m, 6H), 1.65 (sept, 1H,
J = 6.8 Hz), 2.30 (dt, 2H, J = 2.1 and 6.5 Hz), 2.55 (m, 1H), 2.68 (m,
1H), 4.75 (s, 1H), 7.23-7.33 (m, 3H), 7.47 (d, 2H, J = 7.0 Hz). 13C NMR δ
13.6, 18.7, 22.0, 22.2, 22.3, 27.6, 29.7, 30.9, 38.0, 39.1, 77.8, 86.3,
127.3, 127.6, 128.2, 139.1. Anal Calcd for C18H26S: C, 78.77; H, 9.55.
Found: C, 78.50; H, 9.64.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Example 5. This example describes the synthesis of compound 52. To a
stirred solution of EtSH (713 mg, 850 mL, 11.5 mmol) in THF (45 mL) was
added KH (106 mg, 0.93 mmol, 35% in mineral oil). After 30 minutes, the
mixture was cooled to 0°C and a solution of 50 (2.064 g, 3.99 mmol) in
THF (15 mL) was added via cannula over 5 minutes. An additional amount of
THF (10 mL) was added to rinse the flask. After 50 minutes at room
temperature, the reaction was quenched with saturated aqueous NH4Cl (50
mL). Air was bubbled through the solution for 2 hours to remove excess
ETSH. The solution was extracted with Et2O (4×100 mL). The dried (Mg2SO4)
extract was concentrated in vacuo and the residue was crystallized by the
addition of 10% Et2O/petroleum ether to yield the recovered auxiliary
(640 mg, 3.61 mmol, 93%) as a white solid. The decanted solution was
purified by chromatography over silica gel, eluting with 10-30%
Et2O/petroleum ether. Yield: 52 (1.44 g, 3.50 mmol, 90%), colorless oil.
[α]D23-46.1 (c 3.50, CHCl3); IR (neat) 1684 cm-1; 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3)
5.35-5.5 (m, 1H), 4.55 (bs, 1H), 3.9-4.2 (m, 3H), 3.8-3.9 (m, 1H),
3.45-3.6 (m, 1H), 2.75-2.9 (m, 2H), 2.4-2.6 (m, 2H), 1.4-1.9 (m, 6H),
1.21 (t, J=7.5 Hz, 3H), 0.93 (s, 9H), 0.09 (s, 3H), 0.06 (s, 3H of a
diastereomer), 0.05 (s, 3H of a diastereomer); 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3)
δ205.1, 205.0, 135.24, 135.16, 97.9, 97.4, 78.6, 65.7, 65.5, 62.3, 62.2,
34.5, 30.8, 25.9, 25.7, 22.6, 22.1, 22.0, 19.7, 19.6, 18.4, 14.8, -4.7,
-4.8; HRMS (CI) calculated for C2OH37NO4SSi (M+H+) 401.2182, found
401.2172.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM incremental addition THF in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Glycosyl phosphate couplings: General
Procedure D. Glycosyl phosphate donor (1.2 equiv) and acceptor (1.0
equiv) were combined and azeotropically dried with toluene (3 x 5 mL)
followed by 1 h under vacuum. The mixture was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (2
mL/0.10 mmol acceptor) and cooled to -78°C for 15 min before
trimethylsilyltriflate (1.2 equiv) was added dropwise. After stirring for
30 min at -78°C, triethylamine (2 equiv) was added. The solution was
warmed to room temperature and the solvent was removed in a stream of N2.
The resulting mixture was purified by flash silica column chromatography.
Ethyl 3,4,6-tri-O-benzyl-2-O-pivaloyl-1-thio-β -D-glucopyranoside 31.
General Procedure D using donor 3 (42.6 mg, 53.6 μmol), acceptor 26 (4.4
μL, 59 μmol) and TMSOTf (10.9 μL, 59.0 μmol) afforded 28.0 mg (90%) of 31
as a colorless oil after flash silica column chromatography (10%
EtOAc/hexanes). All spectral data were in accordance with published
data.i
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM stereoselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

Triesters as Glycosylating Agents
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

Peter H.

$DATUM Compound 21. t-Butylthiol (11.32 g, 125 mmol) was added to a dry Schlenk
flask and dissolved in dry THF (450 mL) disted from sodium. The solution
was deoxygenated by bubbling nitrogen through it before the flask w as
placed in an ice bath. n-BuLi solution in hexanes (70 mL of 1.6 M) was
then added slowly via syringe over 10 min. This mixture was allowed to
stir for 1 hr., then compound 20 (5.5 g, 16.2 mmol) was added and the
solution was left to reflux at 60°C overnight. The next morning an
aliquot was worked up, analyzed by NMR, and the reaction deemed complete.
The reaction was quenched with HCl (200 mL of 2 M) and extracted with
ether (3 X 250 mL). The ethereal layers were then dried with magnesium
sulfate, filtered, and the filtrate concentrated to yield the product,
compound 21. A white solid, yield: 5 g, 90%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 200 MHz) δ
1.26 (b rs, 26 H), 1.32 (b rs, 9 H), 1.48-1.70 (m, 4 H), 2.35 (t, 2 H, J
= 7.3 Hz), 2.52 (t, 2 H, J = 7.3 Hz). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 200 MHz) 5 24.69,
28.35, 29.05, 29.21,29.28, 29.39, 29.55, 29.89, 31.02(3C), 33.98,
41.75,179.60.

$DATUM t-Butylthiol (11.32 g, 125 mmol) was added to a dry Schlenk flask and
dissolved in dry THF (450 mL) distilled from sodium. The solution was
deoxygenated by bubbling nitrogen through it before the flask was placed
in an ice bath. n-BuLi solution in hexanes (70 mL of 1.6 M) was then
added slowly via syringe over 10 min. This mixture was allowed to stir
for 1 hr., then compound 20 (5.5 g, 16.2 mmol) was added and the solution
was left to reflux at 60° C. overnight. The next morning an aliquot was
worked up, analyzed by NMR, and the reaction deemed complete. The
reaction was quenched with HCl (200 mL of 2 M) and extracted with ether
(3×250 mL). The ethereal layers were then dried with magnesium sulfate,
filtered, and the filtrate concentrated to yield the product, compound
21, as a white solid (5 g, 90% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 200 MHz) δ 1.26 (br
s, 26H), 1.32 (br s, 9H), 1.48-1.70 (m, 4H), 2.35 (t, 2H, J=7.3 Hz), 2.52
(t, 2H, J=7.3 Hz).13C NMR (CDCl3, 200 MHz) δ 24.69, 28.35, 29.05, 29.21,
29.28, 29.39, 29.55, 29.89, 31.02(3C), 33.98, 41.75, 179.60.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Synthesis. [PPh4][MoIV(PPh3)(SCH2CH3)(mnt)2].CH2Cl2(1). To a solution of
4.28 g (4 mmol) of [PPh4]2[MoIVO(mnt)2] and 10.49 g (40 mmol) of PPh3 in
100 mL of dichloromethane at 0 °C was slowly added 1 mL of
methanesulphonic acid with constant stirring. Initial green color of the
solution turned bright red after 10 min, and then 1.77 mL of CH3CH2SH (24
mmol) was added to this solution. Stirring was continued for another 15
min at 0 °C when the solution acquired a dark violet color. Addition of
petroleum ether (60-80 °C) resulted in incipient cloudiness and on
standing overnight at 4 °C dark violet block shaped diffraction quality
crystals separated out. These were filtered, washed with petroleum ether,
and dried under inert atmosphere. Yield 4.046 g, 90% . Analysis required
for C53H42Cl2MoN4P2S5: C, 53.65; H,3.67; N, 4.63; S, 13.26%. Found: C,
53.75; H, 3.76; N, 4.75; S,13.32%. Absorption spectrum (dichloromethane)
λmax (εM): 387(6350), 512 (4920), 555 (3985) nm. IR (KBr pellet):ν 2200
(CN),3055 (aromatic CH stretching), 724 (aromatic CH bending) cm-1.IR
(CsI pellet):ν 352, 345 (MoIV-Sdithiolene), 326 (MoIV-SEt) cm-1.31P NMR:δ
49.88, s. MS: m/z ) 700.908 ([MoIV(PPh3)-(SCH2CH3)(mnt)2]1-), 438.880
([MoIV (SCH2CH3)(mnt)2]1-).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Selectivity of Thiolate Ligand and Preference of Substrate in Model
Reactions of Dissimilatory Nitrate Reductase
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Majumdar, Amit; Pal, Kuntal; Sarkar, Sabyasachi
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Inorganic Chemistry (2008), 47(8), 3393-3401

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure D. β-Phosphate glycosyl
donor (0.12 mmol) and glycosyl acceptor (0.10 mmol) were combined and
azeotropically dried with toluene (3 × 5 mL) followed by 1h under vacuum.
The mixture was dissolved in anh. CH2Cl2 and cooled to -78°C for 15 min.
Trimethylsilyltriflate (22 μL, 0.12 mmol) was added dropwise. After
stirring for 10 min at -78°C, triethylamine (30 μL) was added. The
solution was warmed to room temperature and the solvent was removed in a
stream of N2. The resulting crude product was purified by flash silica
column chromatography to afford fully protected disaccharides and
thioglycosides. Synthesis of Thioethyl
3,4,6-Tri-O-benzyl-2-O-pivaloyl-β-D-glucopyranoside 17. Yield 90%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM MOLECULAR SIEVES USED
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Combinatorial synthesis of oligosaccharide phosphates via glycosidation
reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Seeberger, Peter H.; Plante, Obadiah J.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2000020428 A2 2000-04-13

$DATUM Intermediate 3A: To 2-fluoro-5-nitrobenzaldehyde (25 g, 148 mmol) and
ethylthiol (15.1 mL, 203 mmol) in DMF (100 mL) was added potassium
carbonate (35.8 g, 260 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at 60°C
for 8.0 h. After it cooled to rt, cold water (200 mL) was added and
stirred at rt for 15 min. The precipitate was collected by filtration and
washed with water. After drying, Intermediate 3A (25 g) was obtained as a
yellow solid. The filtrate was extracted with EtOAc, washed with brine
and dried over Na2SO4. After evaporation of solvent, the crude was
triturated with EtOAc/hexane (1:3) to give a second crop of Intermediate
3A (3 g, total 90% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ ppm 1.44 (t, J =
7.47 Hz, 3 H) 3.08 (q, J = 7.47 Hz, 2 H) 7.46 (d, J = 8.79 Hz, 1 H) 8.30
(dd, J = 8.79, 2.64 Hz, 1 H) 8.62 (d, J = 2.20 Hz, 1 H) 10.25 (s, 1 H).

35A: 2-(Ethylthio)-5-nitrobenzaldehyde [00189] To
2-fluoro-5-nitrobenzaldehyde (25 g, 148 mmol) and ethylthiol (15.1 mL,
203 mmol) in DMF (100 mL) was added potassium carbonate (35.8 g, 260
mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at 60 °C for 8.0 h. After it
cooled to rt, cold water (200 mL) was added and stirred at rt for 15 min.
The precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with water. After
drying, 35A (25 g) was obtained as a yellow solid. The filtrate was
extracted with EtOAc, washed with brine and dried over Na2SO4. After
evaporation of solvent, the crude was triturated with EtOAc/hexane (1:3)
to give a second crop of 35A (3 g, total 90% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz,
CDCl3) δ ppm 1.44 (t, J=7.47 Hz, 3H) 3.08 (q, J=7.47 Hz, 2H) 7.46 (d,

$DATUM 127-19-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Preparation of octadecyl-thio-benzonitrile in accordance with the
following reaction scheme: The reaction is carried out under an inert
atmosphere in a 5-necked 750 ml sulfonating flask provided with a
thermometer, a mechanical stirrer, a dropping funnel and a reflux
condenser. 100.00 g (0.35 mol, 1.0 eq.) of 1-octadecanethiol are
dissolved in 200 ml of dimethylacetamide (DMA) at 30°C and added over 25
minutes to a white suspension of 48.18 g (0.35 mol, 1.0 eq.) of
p-chlorobenzonitrile and 67.72 g (0.49 mol, 1.4 eq.) of finely ground
potassium carbonate in 200 ml of dimethylacetamide. The reaction mixture
is then heated to 135°C and stirred at that temperature for 4 hours. The
temperature is then reduced to 80°C and the reaction mixture is stirred
for 16 hours to complete the reaction. The reaction mixture is then
discharged into 1600.0 g of water at room temperature. The white
crystalline solid that precipitates out over one hour is filtered off and
dried at 70°C and 200 mbar. There are obtained 122.6 g (90.4 % of theory)
of the compound of formula octadecyl-thio-benzonitrile, 122.6 g (90.4 %)
yield
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Heat-stable diketopyrrolopyrrole pigment mixtures for cosmetics
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Wallquist, Olof; Lenz, Roman; Feiler, Leonhard; Dueggeli, Mathias;
Yousaf, Taher; De Keyzer, Gerardus
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2005040284 A1 2005-05-06

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Coupling of
Functionalized Aryl Bromides and Iodides with Aliphatic and Aromatic
Thiols. The appropriate quantity of stock solution A or B was added to a
4 mL vial containing the aryl bromide or iodide (1.00 mmol) and LiHMDS or
Cs2CO3 (2.4 mmol) as base, unless otherwise stated, in DME (1.5 mL). The
thiol (1.00 mmol) was then added and the vial was sealed with a cap
containing a PTFE septum. The mixture was heated at the temperature
indicated in Tables 6 and 7 until the aryl halide was consumed, as
determined by GC. Silica gel (0.5 g) was added, and the solvents were
evaporated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel with hexane or a mixture of hexane
and ethyl acetate as eluent. Aryl sulfides were isolated in the yields
reported in Tables 6 and 7. Reactions of haloarenes bearing aromatic or
aliphatic hydroxyl groups and LiHMDS as base initially form the
corresponding sulfide with the hydroxyl group protected as the silyl
ether. However the silyl group was removed by treatment with acid (1 N
HCl) prior to the chromatographic purification.
3-(2-Methyl-2-propylsulfanyl)benzaldehyde (Table 6, entry 23).8 Colorless
oil, yield 90% 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 10.03 (s, 1H), 8.02 (t, J = 1.6 Hz, 1H),
7.88 (dt, J = 7.6 Hz and 1.6 Hz, 1H), 7.79 (dt, J = 7.6 Hz and 1.6 Hz,
1H), 7.51 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 1.31 (s, 9H). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 191.5,
143.0, 138.2, 136.5, 134.2, 129.4, 128.9, 46.2, 30.7 (3C).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM silica gel used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A General, Efficient, and Functional-Group-Tolerant Catalyst System for
the Palladium-Catalyzed Thioetherification of Aryl Bromides and Iodides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Fernandez-Rodriguez, Manuel A.; Hartwig, John F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2009), 74(4), 1663-1672

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM [0080] To a solution of 16.2 g (0.120 mol) of sulfuryl chloride in 50 mL
of toluene, was added dropwise, 17.5 g (0.240 mol) of diethylamine in 25
mL of toluene, over 1 hour, with ice cooling. The solution was stirred
for 4 hours, with ice cooling, and then cold water was added to it, to
perform extraction. Further, the resultant solution was washed with cold
water, twice, to yield a solution of N,N-diethylsulfamoyl chloride in
toluene. [0081] The resultant solution of N,N-diethylsulfamoyl chloride
in toluene was added to a solution containing 19.5 g (0.100 mol) of
4-t-butyl-2-nitrophenol and 16.6 g (0.120 mol) of potassium carbonate in
15 ml of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). The resultant solution was stirred
at 70 °C for 4 hours. Ethyl acetate and water were added to the reaction
solution, to extract the reaction product. The organic phase was washed
with 0.1 N potassium carbonate aqueous solution, diluted hydrochloric
acid, and saturated brine, to yield a reaction solution of Exemplified
compound (2B). [0082] To the resultant reaction solution of Exemplified
compound (2B) were added 17.5 g (0.120 mol) of 2-ethylhexylmercaptan and
2.78 g (0.010 mol) of tetrabutylammonium bromide, and to that was added
50 mL of 25% sodium hydroxide aqueous solution. The resultant solution
was then stirred at 60 °C for 2 hours. To the reaction solution were
added ethyl acetate and water, to extract the reaction product. The
organic phase was washed with diluted hydrochloric acid and saturated
brine, followed by drying over anhydrous magnesium sulfate. The result
was filtered and then the solvent was distilled off under reduced
pressure. The remaining product was purified by silica gel
chromatography, using a mixed solvent of ethyl acetate and hexane as an
eluent, to yield 29.2 g (0.0903 mol) of Exemplified compound (1), as a
yellow oil substance. Yield: 90.3%. In the present example, nuclear
magnetic resonance analysis (1H-NMR, 400 MHz, CDCI3) was performed, in
the same manner as in Examples 2-1 and 2-2. As a result, the very same
spectrum as in Example 2-1 was obtained as to the number of signals, the
positions thereof, and splitting. Accordingly, the above-mentioned yellow
oil substance was identified as Exemplified compound (1).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 3-(t-Butylthiomethyl)-1-phenylpyrrolidine-2,5-dione (130a):
Representative procedures for enantioselective protonation reaction of
itaconimide with thiol catalyzed by chiral bicyclic guanidine: 225 microL
(2.00 mmol, 20.0 equiv.) of t-butyl thiol was dissolved in toluene (0.50
mL) in a 4 mL sample vial. Catalyst 7c (2.23 mg, 0.0100 mmol, 0.100
equiv.) was added and the vial was submerged in cryobath at -20 degC.
After being stirred for 10 min, itaconimide 126b (18.7 mg, 0.100 mmol,
1.00 equiv.) was added as solid and stirred for 2 hours. The reaction was
monitored by TLC. Upon completion of the reaction, the reaction mixture
was loaded onto silica gel column. It was purified by gradient elution
(hexane/EtOAc = 25/1 to 2/1) to afford product 130a with a yield of 90 %.
For aromatic thiols, 1.10 equivalents were used instead of 20.0
equivalents. According to the representative procedure, the title
compound was obtained. White solid; 90 % yield. [alpha 29 D] = +15.9 deg
(c = 2.3 in CHCl3).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM (2010), (20140701), No pp.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM (E)-isopropyl(styryl)sulfane (Table 4, entry 2): The general procedure
was used to convert propane-2-thiol and (E)-1-(2-iodovinyl)benzene to the
title product in 4 hours.Purification by flash chromatography (silica
gel) (5% ethyl acetate in mixture of 3% triethylamine in hexane as the
eluent) gave the analytically pure product as a colorless oil (320 mg,
89% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.30-7.26 (m, 4H), 7.21-7.15
(m,1H), 6.77-6.73 (d, J= 15.6 Hz; 1H), 6.58-6.54 (d, J= 15.6 Hz; 1H),
3.27-3.17 (septet, J=6.7 Hz; 1H), 1.36-1.34 (d, J= 6.7 Hz; 6H). 13C NMR
(100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 137.04, 128.78,128.55, 126.89, 125.54, 124.03, 36.79,
23.36. Anal. Calc’d. for C11H14S: C -74.10; H -7.91; S -17.98; Found, C
-73.82; H -7.91; S -18.03.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Procedure S: To a stirred solution of
ethanethiol (1.31mL, 17.7mmol) in dimethylsulfoxide (10mL) was added
potassium carbonate (4.45g, 32.2mmol) and 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (2g,
16.1mmol). The reaction mixture was heated to 100 °C and stirred for 16
hours. The reaction mixture was then allowed to cool to room temperature
and poured into water. The aqueous phase was extracted with ethyl acetate
(x3) then the combined organic layers were washed (water then twice with
brine), dried over sodium sulfate and concentrated in vacuo to afford
4-(ethylthio)benzaldehyde Procedure S (using propane-2-thiol, 90% yield).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM EXAMPLE 1. 4-tert-butylthiobenzaldehyde. To a solution of t-butylthiol
(22.5 g, 0.25 mol) in 80 ml of DMSO containing potassium carbonate (33.0
g, 0.24 mol), 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (30.0 g, 0.24 mol) was added and the
mixture was heated at 100°C. for 3 hours with stirring. After cooling the
reaction mixture was poured into water, and the mixture was extracted
with ether. The extracts were dried by MgSO4 and evaporated to dryness.
Distillation of the residue gave 42.0 g 4-tert-butylthiobenzaldehyde (90%
yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ 10.03 (s, 1H), 7.83 (d, 2H, J=8.0 Hz),
7.69 (d, 2H, J=8.0 Hz), 1.34 (s, 9H).

$DATUM United States, US7449578 B1 2008-11-11

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-356-CAS-6076935
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 90
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 121-44-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 543-27-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM tert-Butyl (S)-2-(Ethylthiocarbonyl)-5-oxopyrrolidine-1-carboxylate (9).
Isobutyl chloroformate (0.89 g, 0.85 mL, 6.50 mmol) and Et3N (0.76 g,
1.05 mL, 7.53 mmol) were added to a cold (0 °C) solution of
(S)-1-(tert-butoxycarbonyl)-5-oxopyrrolidine-2-carboxylic acid (8; 1.14
g, 4.95 mmol) in THF (17 mL), under an argon atmosphere. The reaction
mixture was vigorously stirred for 30 min at 0 °C; then ethanethiol (0.70
g, 0.85 mL, 11.36 mmol) and Et3N (0.76 g, 1.05 mL, 7.53 mmol) were added.
The resulting solution was stirred for 30 min at 0 °C and 45 min at r.t.
The mixture was diluted with CH2Cl2 (25 mL) and the organic layer was
washed with H2O (40 mL). The aqueous layer was extracted with CH2Cl2 (2 ×
30 mL), the combined organic extracts were dried (MgSO4), and
concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by
dry-flash chromatography (SiO2; eluent: PE-EtOAc, 7:3) to give the title
compound. Yield: 1.22 g (90%); colorless crystals. mp 53-56 °C (Lit. 8 mp
58.7-60.9 °C); Rf = 0.47 (SiO2, PE-EtOAc, 7:3); [α]D20 -45.9 (c 1.05,
CHCl3) {Lit. [α]D20 -47.4 (c 1.02, CHCl3)}. IR (ATR): 2974, 2931, 2874,
1797, 1707, 1678, 1369, 1309, 1257, 1160, 1025, 992, 842 cm-1. 1H NMR
(500 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 4.72 (dd, J = 9.6, 2.6 Hz, 1 H), 3.03-2.90 (m, 2
H), 2.66 (ddd, J = 17.6, 10.2, 9.8 Hz, 1 H), 2.49 (ddd, J = 17.6, 9.5,
3.1 Hz, 1 H), 2.40-2.28 (m, 1 H), 2.09-1.99 (m, 1 H), 1.50 (s, 9 H), 1.29
(t, J = 7.4 Hz, 3 H). 13C NMR (126 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 199.1 (C), 173.3 (C),
148.8 (C), 83.7 (C), 65.2 (CH), 30.7 (CH2), 27.8 (CH3), 23.1 (CH2), 22.2
(CH3), 14.5 (CH3). HRMS (ESI): m/z calcd for C12H19NO4S [M + Na]+:
296.0927; found: 296.0933. Anal. Calcd for C12H19NO4S: C, 52.73; H, 7.01;
N, 5.12; S, 11.73. Found: C, 52.63; H, 6.99; N, 5.12; S, 11.57.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Formal synthesis of (-)-oseltamivir phosphate
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Trajkovic, Milos; Ferjancic, Zorana; Saicic, Radomir N.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2013), 45(3), 389-395

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: ω-Phosphonodithioesters 13a,b. To a stirred
solution of cyanomethylphosphonate 12a (MERCK or ACROS) (17.7 g, 0.1 mol)
or ω-cyanophosphonate 12b (21.9 g, 0.1 mol) in chloroform (100 mL) cooled
at 0 °C, ethanethiol, 2 equiv (12.4 g, 0.2 mol), was added. The
conversion nitrile-dithioester was realized according to the procedures
described previously for 1a-d. After confirmation that the reaction was
complete by IR (no nitrile signal near 2250 cm-1), hydrogen sulfide was
passed through the suspension of imidothioester chlorhydrate in CHCl3
(100 mL) using 2 equiv PVPr (23 g). The orange dithioesters 13a and 13b
were purified by distation under reduced pressure. Diethyl
[4-(Ethylthiothiocarbonyl)]butylphosphonate (13b). Yield: 90%, orange
liquid. Eb710-4 = 70 °C. 1H NMR (CDCl3): 1.30 (9H, t J = 7 Hz, CH3), 1.60
(2H, dt JHH = 7 Hz, CH3), 1.60 (2H, dt JHH = 7 Hz, JHP = 20 Hz, PCH2),
1.00-2.00 (4H, m, CH2), 3.00 (2H, t, J = 7 Hz 2H, CH2CS2), 3.15 (2H, q J
= 6 Hz, SCH2), 4.10 (4H, dq JHOP = JHH = 7 Hz, OCH2). 13C NMR (CCl4):
12.14 (s, CH2CH3), 16.43 (d JCCOP = 6 Hz, CH3CH2O), 26.03 (d JCP = 183
Hz, PCH2), 30.85 (d JCCP = 12 Hz, PCH2CH2), 31.17 (CH2); 32.04 (SCH2),
51.24 (CH2CS2), 61.34 (d JCOP = 6.5 Hz, OCH2), 237.95 (C=S). 31P NMR
(CDCl3): 31.46. UV-vis (CH2Cl2): 307.5 (log ε = 4.01). IR (CHCl3): 1160
(P-O), 1230 (PdO). Anal. Calcd for C11H23O3PS2 (298.40): C, 44.27; H,
7.77; O, 16.08; P, 10.38; S, 21.49. Found: C, 44.10; H, 7.81; O, 16.33;
P, 11,07; S, 21.15. Mass: 298 (M+·, 4), 282 (9), 269 (15), 253 (24), 237
(54), 193 (12), 179 (56), 165 (25), 152 (81), 137 (48), 81 (52), 71 (35),
55 (100), 41 (30).

$DATUM 110-71-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Coupling of
Functionalized Aryl Bromides and Iodides with Aliphatic and Aromatic
Thiols. The appropriate quantity of stock solution A or B was added to a
4 mL vial containing the aryl bromide or iodide (1.00 mmol) and LiHMDS or
Cs2CO3 (2.4 mmol) as base, unless otherwise stated, in DME (1.5 mL). The
thiol (1.00 mmol) was then added and the vial was sealed with a cap
containing a PTFE septum. The mixture was heated at the temperature
indicated in Tables 6 and 7 until the aryl halide was consumed, as
determined by GC. Silica gel (0.5 g) was added, and the solvents were
evaporated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel with hexane or a mixture of hexane
and ethyl acetate as eluent. Aryl sulfides were isolated in the yields
reported in Tables 6 and 7. Reactions of haloarenes bearing aromatic or
aliphatic hydroxyl groups and LiHMDS as base initially form the
corresponding sulfide with the hydroxyl group protected as the silyl
ether. However the silyl group was removed by treatment with acid (1 N
HCl) prior to the chromatographic purification.
4-(2-Methyl-2-propylsulfanyl)phenol (Table 6, entries 1 and 4).16 White
solid, yield 90% 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.39 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 6.80 (d, J =
8.5 Hz, 2H), 5.62 (bs, 1 H), 1.26 (s, 9H). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 156.3,
139.0 (2C), 123.4, 115.5 (2C), 45.6, 30.6 (3C).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM silica gel used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A General, Efficient, and Functional-Group-Tolerant Catalyst System for
the Palladium-Catalyzed Thioetherification of Aryl Bromides and Iodides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Fernandez-Rodriguez, Manuel A.; Hartwig, John F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2009), 74(4), 1663-1672

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: (Z)-1-alkylthio-2-p-tolylsulphonylstilbenes
(5a-i) General Method To a solution of sodium ethoxide (5.5 mg atom of
sodium dissolved in 10 ml of abs. ethanol) an appropriate alkanethiol
(5.5 m mole) was added. The resulting alkanethiolate solution was mixed
with a solution of 2 (5.5 m mol) in ethanol (50 ml) and refluxed. Reflux
time varied from 3 to 6 h, in different cases. The solution upon cooling
deposited the (Z)-1-alkylthio-2-p-tolylsulphonylstilbenes (5) as
crystalline material, which was recrystallized from 95% ethanol or any
other suitable solvent. (Z)-1-t-butylthio-2-p-tolylsulphonylstilbene (5g)
Recrystallized from aqueous ethanol as shining needles, yield 89.7%. m.p,
95-96°C. Found:C, 71.02; H, 6.02; S, 14.98. C25H26O2S2 requires C, 71.06;
H, 6.20; S, 15.14 %). EIMS: m/z (rel.into %) 422(10), 333(4), 287(15),
269(30), 267(11), 212(10), 211(47), 210(18), 180(34), 179(23), 178(100),
176(10), 167(5), 165(8), 155(11), 139(8), 123(6), 121(10),
105(23),98(10), 91(26), 73(29), 71(27), 69(49), 67(10), 57(9), and
43(38).

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Typical Procedure for the Synthesis of 3:
5-Benzyloxymethyl-5-methyl-3-(methylthiomethyl)-2-isoxazoline (Entry 1 in
Table 1) To a suspension of NaH (0.05 g, 1.24 mmol, 60% Aldrich) in THF
(7 mL) was added methanethiol (0.06 g, 1.24 mmol) by a syringe at 0°C and
the mixture was stirred 10 min at r.t. A solution of
5-benzyloxymethyl-3-(3,3-dimethyloxiranyl)-5-methyl-2-isoxazoline (0.20
g, 0.73 mmol) in THF (3 mL) was added to the reaction mixture and stirred
for 30 min at 25°C. It was poured into cold water and extracted with
EtOAc. The organic phase was washed with brine, dried over anhydrous
MgSO4, and concentrated. The residue was purified by silica gel column
chromatography (EtOAc/Hexane, 1/9) to afford
5-benzyloxymethyl-5-methyl-3-(methylthiomethyl)-2-isoxazoline (0.16 g,
85%) as a pale yellow oil.
5-Benzyloxymethyl-3-(ethylthiomethyl)-5-methyl-2-isoxazoline (Entry 2):
Pale yellow oil; yield 90%. 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ 1.19 (t, 3H, J = 7.4 Hz),
1.37 (s, 3H), 2.43 (q, 2H, J = 7.4 Hz), 2.71 (d, 1H, J = 17.1 Hz), 3.19
(d, 1H, J = 17.1 Hz), 3.33 (s, 2H), 3.44 (qAB, 2H, J = 9.9, 14.0 Hz),
4.56 (qAB, 2H, J = 13.6, 15.6 Hz), 7.23-7.32 (m, 5H); MS m/z (relative
intensity) 280 (M+ + 1, 0.47), 218 (36.20), 187 (12.07), 157 (30.37), 129
(10.10), 96 (25.39), 91 (100), 75 (55.57), 65 (7.89); HRMS calcd. for
C15H21NO2S 279.1280, found 279.1293.

$DATUM 67-56-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 1-Bromo-1-(tert-butylsulfonyl)pentane. A mixture of
2-bromo-1-phenylhexan-1-one (5.10 g, 20.0 mmol), 2-methyl-2-propanethiol
(1.80 g, 20.0 mmol), benzyltriethylammonium bromide (0.272 g, 1.00 mmol),
and NaOH (3.00 g, 75.0 mmol) in dichloromethane (40 mL) and water (40 mL)
in a 250-mL round-bottom flask was stirred at r.t. for 8 h. Then, water
(100 mL) was added, and the mixture was extracted with dichloromethane (3
× 50 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over MgSO4 and
concentrated. The residue was dissolved in MeOH (50 mL) and water (50
mL), and then oxone ® (30.7 g, 100 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture
was stirred at r.t. overnight, and most of the MeOH was removed under
reduced pressure. The resulting aqueous mixture was extracted with
dichloromethane (3 × 30 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over
MgSO4 and concentrated. 2-(tert-Butylsulfonyl)-1-phenylhexan-1-one was
purified by column chromatography (5% → 60% ethyl acetate/hexanes): 5.34
g (90%). White solid.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
