$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136(34), 12161-12165

$DATUM 2'-Deoxy-2'-(t-butyldithio)cytidine.
2'-Deoxy-2'-(2-nitrophenyldithio)-cytidine)5d (70 mg, 0.170 mmol) was
dissolved in 10% MeOH/CHCl3 (10 mL). In a separate flask,
2-methyl-2-propanethiol (115 μL, 1.02 mmol), triethylamine (277 μL), and
methanol (2.8 mL) were combined. The solution was transferred to the
reaction flask and stirred for 3 h at room temperature. The reaction was
concentrated, and the residue was purified by column chromatography
(0-10% MeOH in CHCl3) to give the product as a white solid in 90% yield.
1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ 7.77 (d, 1H, J = 7.5 Hz), 6.06 (d, 1H, J = 9.0
Hz), 5.81 (d, 1H, J = 7.4 Hz), 4.30 (m, 1H), 3.89 (m, 1H), 3.61 (m, 3H),
1.14 (s, 9H). MS (ESI): calculated for C13H22N3O4S2 (MH+) 348.10; found
348.1.

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Synthesis of Thioacetals; Typical Procedure A
solution of pyrrole 1c (0.20 g, 1 mmol), ethanethiol (0.20 g, 3 mmol) and
TFA (0.005 g, 0.25% with respect to total mass) in benzene (2 mL) was
kept at r.t. until consumption of 1c was complete (~1 h; monitored by
GLC). NaHCO3 (0.10 g) was added and the mixture was shaken before the
liquid phase was decanted off and the solid residue was washed with
benzene (3 × 0.5 mL). Purification of the crude product by column
chromatography (Al2O3; n-hexane-Et2O, 2:1) gave the pure product 2c.
2-[Bis(ethylsulfanyl)methyl]-1-vinylpyrrole (2a) Red viscous oil, yield
90%. nD20 1.4640. IR (KBr): 3113, 3089, 3035, 2968, 2926, 2870, 1685,
1670, 1640, 1563, 1544, 1523, 1507, 1475, 1449, 1422, 1375, 1358, 1310,
1290, 1265, 1219, 1200, 1156, 1122, 1093, 1072, 1054, 1036, 1014, 969,
883, 865, 792, 772, 742, 719, 679, 654, 594, 520 cm-1. 1H NMR (400 MHz,
CDCl3): δ = 7.31 (dd, JB-X = 15.4 Hz, JA-X = 8.8 Hz, 1 H, HX), 6.97 (dd,
J = 3.2, 1.7 Hz, 1 H, H-5), 6.21 (dd, J = 3.4, 1.7 Hz, 1 H, H-3), 6.08
(dd, J = 3.4, 3.2 Hz, 1 H, H-4), 5.11 (d, JB-X = 15.4 Hz, 1 H, HB), 6.06
(s, 1 H, CH), 4.74 (d, JA-X = 8.8 Hz, 1 H, HA), 2.61 (m, 2 H, CH2), 2.53
(m, 2 H, CH2), 1.22 (t, 6 H, J = 7.3 Hz, CH3). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3):
δ = 131.42 (C-α ), 128.52 (C-2), 118.65 (C-5), 111.36 (C-3), 109.18
(C-4), 99.00 (C-b), 44.86 (CH), 25.83 (CH2), 14.49 (CH3). Anal. Calcd for
C11H17NS2: C, 58.11; H, 7.54; N, 6.16; S, 28.20. Found: C, 58.17; H,
7.43; N, 6.12; S, 28.29.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM meso-Tetraphenyl-3-ethioxy-2-oxachlorin (13-SEt). General Procedure for
the Conversion of Hemiacetals 11H2 to RS-based Thiaacetals 13-SR. Excess
ethanethiol (1 to 2 mL) was added to a stirring solution of 11H2 (10 mg,
0.015 mmol) in CHCl3 (3-5 mL) at room temperature. Traces of TFA vapors
(from a TFA bottle head space, delivered via pipet) were added, and the
reaction was monitored by TLC. The reaction was complete within 3-5 h.
Upon completion, the acid was neutralized with Et3N (1 drop), the
solution washed, dried over anhydrous MgSO4, evaporated to dryness using
rotary evaporation, and purified by silica gel flash column or
preparative plate chromatography (CH2Cl2). Yield 90% (9.6 mg). Rf
(silica-CH2Cl2) = 0.96; 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3, δ ): 8.50-8.52 (m, 1H),
8.43-8.44 (m, 1H), 8.33-8.35 (m, 2H), 8.26- 8.27 (m, 1H), 7.99 (m, 8H),
7.90-7.91 (m, 1H), 7.67-7.80 (m, 12H), 2.31-2.41 (m, 1H), 2.12-2.19 (m,
1H), 0.89-0.93 (m, 3H), -0.30 (s, 1H), -0.65 (s, 1H) ppm; 13C NMR (100
MHz, CDCl3, δ ): 165.9, 154.9, 153.1, 151.9, 143.4, 141.9, 141.8, 141.4,
139.9, 138.7, 136.8, 135.5, 134.6, 134.1, 133.9, 133.8, 133.3, 131.6,
131.1, 129.9, 128.5, 128.2, 128.0, 127.92, 127.94, 127.97, 127.8, 127.7,
127.1, 126.95, 126.9, 126.3, 124.9, 121.8, 110.6, 100.1, 90.8 ppm;
UV-visible (CH2Cl2) λmax (log ε ): 420 (5.31), 457 (4.43), 518 (4.13),
555 (4.07), 608 (3.88), 660 (4.51) nm; LR-MS (ESI+, 100% CH3CN, 30 V cone
voltage): m/z 679.1 (MH+), upon exposure to ambient light and
environment, significant peak of 695.7 (MHO+) is observed; HR-MS (ESI+,
100% CH3CN, TOF): m/z calcd for C45H35N4OS (MH+): 679.2532, found
679.2471.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 90
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-63-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 121-44-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Ethyl-2-O-acetyl-3,4,6-tri-O-benzyl-α /β -D-1-thio-mannopyranoside (S5).
To a 250 mL round bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stir bar and a
positive pressure argon inlet was added S4 (5.20 g, 9.73 mmol) in dry
CH2Cl2 (25 mL). To the solution was added ethanethiol (3.02 g, 2.11 mL,
48.6 mmol), followed by the addition of boron trifluoride etherate (6.64
g, 5.88 mL, 48.6 mmol). After 30 min the reaction was neutralized with
triethylamine (4 mL) and concentrated under reduced pressure. The
resulting syrup was partitioned between CH2Cl2 and water. The organic
layer was washed with a saturated aqueous NaHCO3 solution (2 x 50 mL) and
water (2 x 50 mL). The solution was dried with MgSO4, filtered, and
concentrated under reduced pressure. The resulting yellow oil was
purified ,by column chromatography (85: 15 hexanes:ethyl acetate) to
yield S5 (4.77 g, 90%) as a colorless oil. Crystallization occurs upon
standing. Rf 0.52 (4:1 hexanes:ethyl acetate). (α /β = 8:1)
Ethyl-2-O-acetyl-3,4,6-tri-O-benzyl-α /β -D-1-thio-mannopyranoside (S5),
yield 4.77 g, 90%
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Synthesis and Conformational Investigation of Methyl
4a-Carba-D-arabinofuranosides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Callam, Christopher S.; Lowary, Todd L.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2001), 66(26), 8961-8972

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Procedure for a Nucleophilic Addition of
TsMeNH. (Styrene)Cr(CO)3 (1a) (20.4 mg, 0.085 mmol), KOH (7.2 mg, 0.13
mmol), TsMeNH (31.5 mg, 0.17 mmol) and 18-crown-6 ether (4.5 mg, 0.017
mmol) were dissolved in 0.20 mL of THF in a Schlenk tube. The solution
was stirred at 60°C for 45 h. After 45 h, the solvent were evaporated.
The crude products were purified by thin-layer chromatography
(toluene/AcOEt = 10/1, with NEt3) to give analytically pure 3aa (74%) as
yellow solid. Compound 4da; yield: 90%. Yellow oil, 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400
MHz) δ 1.24 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H), 1.35 (d, J = 5.6 Hz, 3H), 2.51 (q, J =
7.2 Hz, 2H), 2.63-2.76 (m, 3H), 5.31 (br s, 5H); 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz)
δ 14.7, 19.6, 26.9, 38.2, 40.5, 91.5, 92.0, 92.1, 92.3, 93.9, 116.6,
233.0; IR (neat) 2970, 2929, 1961, 1871, 1523, 1458, 1419, 1265, 816,
750, 661, 633, 536 cm-1. HRMS (FAB, positive) m/z Calcd. for:
C14H16CrO3S, 316.0225 ([M]+); Found: 316.0223 ([M]+).

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General procedure (1) NaH (60% in mineral oil) was slowly added to a THF
solution of alkylthiol and stirred for 15- 20 min at room temperature.
This solution was added to bromoacetaldehyde dimethoxyacetal in THF and
the reaction was refluxed overnight, washed water, brine and extracted
with CH2Cl2 (20- 25 mL). The organic layer was dried over anhydrous NaSO4
and removed under vacuum to give the product used directly in the next
step. 1,1-Dimethoxy-2-ethythioethane: From 2.00 g (32.3 mmol) of
1-ethylthiol, 1.55 g (38.8 mmol) of NaH (60% in mineral oil) and 6 g
(35.5 mmol) of bromoacetaldehyde dimethylacetal in THF (10 mL): 4.77 g,
(90%). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ: 4.49 (t, 1H, J = 5.5 Hz), 3.37 (s, 6H),
2.70 (d, 2H, J = 5.6 Hz), 2.61 (q, 2H, J = 7.4 Hz), 1.26 (t, 3H, J = 7.4
Hz).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 36567-04-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-026-CAS-9837930
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 90
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1310-73-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Sodium mercaptide (1.2 mol) as 20 % solution in water was placed into a
flask and 40 g (1 mol) of NaOH (solid) was added under stirring. The
mixture was intensively stirred and 169 g (1 mol) of
2-ammonio-2-methlypropylsulfate was added within 30 min. The mixture was
then stirred for 5-10 h at 90°C and cooled to 30°C. The upper organic
layer was separated to give 169 g of the product
2-methyl-1-(methlythio)propane-2-amine with a purity of 53 % (47 % water
content). The product can be dried over MgSO4 or azeotropically with
hexane to give 1 10 g (90 % of theory) of the amine with purity of 97 %.
B.p. 55 -58°C / 25 mbar.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM reactant assumed
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Preparation of thioalkylamines from chlorosulfonic acid and aminoalcohols

$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Sodium mercaptide (1.2 mol) as 20 % solution in water was placed into a
flask and 40 g (1 mol) of NaOH (solid) was added under stirring. The
mixture was intensively stirred and 169 g (1 mol) of ground
2-ammonio-2-methlypropylsulfate was added within 30 min. The mixture was
then stirred for 5-10 h at 9O°C and cooled to 30°C. The upper organic
layer was separated to give 169 g of the product
2-Methyl-1-(methlythio)propane-2-amine with a purity of 53 % (47 % water
content). The product can be dried over MgSO4 or azeotropically with
Hexane to give 110 g (90 % of theory) of the amine with purity of 97 %.
B.p. 55-58°C / 25 mbar.

$DATUM 2-Chlorothioanisole (2).3b,8 A flask was equipped with a gas outlet
bubbler leading to a mechanically stirred aqueous sodium hypochlorite
scrubber. The flask was charged with N,N-dimethylformamide (30 L),
1,2-dichlorobenzene (1, 5.0 L, 6.5 kg, 44.4 mol), and finely ground
potassium hydroxide (2.7 kg, 48.9 mol, 1.1 equiv). Methyl mercaptan (3
equiv estimated) was introduced into the flask over 3.5 h through the gas
inlet tube, below the surface of the reaction mixture. During this time,
the gas addition had caused an exothermic heating of the reaction
mixture, increasing the internal reaction temperature to 60 °C, and this
temperature was maintained throughout the gas addition. The methyl
mercaptan flow was then terminated, and the reaction mixture was heated
at 100 °C for 1.5 h. The reaction mixture was then cooled to room
temperature over 12 h. Water (28 L) was added to the reaction mixture,
and the resulting solution was extracted with hexanes (2 × 10 L). The
combined organic layers were washed with water (12 L) and saturated
aqueous sodium chloride solution (2 L). The solvent was removed under
reduced pressure (30 mmHg vacuum, final bath temperature 45 °C) on a
rotary evaporator. 2 as an opaque, light-yellow oil that was suitable for
further use without purification (6.36 kg, 90% yield). TLC Rf (1:19 ethyl
acetate/hexanes) = 0.72; 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.36-7.08 (m, 4H),
2.48 (s, 3H); ESI MS m/z 158 [M]+. The spectral data were also identical
to those of a sample obtained commercially.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM exothermic

$DATUM Organic Process Research & Development (2012), 16(4), 550-555

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Representative procedure for
3-Phenylthiocyclohexan-1-one1 (entry 1, table 1):: Cyclohexenone (0.24 g,
2.5 mmol) in water (5 mL) was treated with thiophenol (0.303 g,2.75 mmol,
1.1 equiv) under magnetic stirring at room temperature (30-35°C) till
complete consumption of the starting material (5 min: TLC, IR). The
reaction mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 10 mL). The combined EtOAc
extracts were dried(Na2SO4) and concentrated under reduced pressure to
afford an oil which on passing through a column of silica-gel and elution
with EtOAc-hexane afforded β-phenylthiocyclohexanone (0.464 g, 90%) as
colorless oil, identical (IR, NMR and MS)with an authentic sample.
Colorless oil, yield 90%. 4-Ethylthio-butan-2-one (entry 16, table 1):
Colorless oily liquid, Yield 90%. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 300 MHz) δ: 1.25 (t, J =
7.2 Hz, 3H), 2.17 (s, 3H), 2.54 (q, JAB = 14.7 Hz, 2H), 2.74 (s, 4H).

$DATUM Thioacetal To a solution of 37 (18.7 mg, 0.0231 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (0.4 mL)
were added ethanethiol (50 μL) and Zn(OTf)2 (9.2 mg, 0.0254 mmol) at rt
under argon atmosphere. After stirring at rt for 4 h, MeOH (0.2 mL) and
CSA (1.1 mg, 0.0046 mmol) were added and the mixture was stirred at rt
for 30min. The mixture was diluted with Et2O, washed with sat. NaHCO3
solution, dried over MgSO4, and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was
purified by flash column chromatography (SiO2; n-hexane:EtOAc = 4:1) to
give thioacetal (16.7 mg, 90% yield). thioacetal, yield (16.7 mg, 90%)
[α]25D + 45.1 (c 1.0, CHCl3); IR (neat) 3464, 2955, 2931, 1472, 1428,
1256, 1089, 1062, 908, 835, 736 cm-1; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.73-7.62
(m, 4H), 7.45-7.33 (m, 6H), 5.23 (br s, 1H), 4.92 (br s, 1H), 4.17 (d, J
= 14.3 Hz, 1H), 4.13 (d, J = 14.3 Hz, 1H), 4.03-3.83 (m, 4H), 3.79-3.67
(m, 3H), 3.07-2.92 (m, 2H), 2.73-2.47 (m, 4H), 2.32-2.37 (m,2H), 2.14
(ddd, J = 14.5, 7.7, 3.4 Hz, 1H), 2.06 (br s, 1H), 1.94 (dt, J = 11.2,
4.0 Hz, 1H), 1.82 (dd, J = 12.9, 1.4 Hz, 1H), 1.64 (ddd, J = 11.2, 11.2,
11.2 Hz, 1H), 1.56 (dd, J = 14.5, 2.9 Hz, 1H), 1.26 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 3H),
1.25 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 3H), 1.21 (s, 3H), 1.06 (s, 9H), 0.90 (s, 9H), 0.05
(s, 3H), 0.03 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 145.9, 135.4, 133.6,
129.5, 127.5, 110.8, 85.7, 79.3, 75.0, 72.6, 71.5, 67.6, 66.3, 63.6,
62.1, 60.0, 40.7, 37.3, 34.4, 30.7, 26.9, 26.0, 23.9, 23.4, 19.4, 18.4,

(M+Na+) 823.3894, found 823.3888.

$DATUM 4-Amino-5-ethylsulfanyl-2-trifluoromethyl-benzonitrile
4-Amino-5-iodo-2-trifluoromethyl-benzonitrile (6.24 g, 20.0 mmol), CuI
(I) (380 mg, 2.0 mmol ), K2CO3 (6.52 g, 40.0 mmol) and ethyl thiol (1.25
g, 20.0 mmol) were mixed in ethanol (50 mL). The reaction was refluxed
overnight and then solvent was removed under vacuum. Upon separation on
silica gel (100% DCM), the tile compound was obtained in pure form as a
colorless liquid (4.36 g, 90%). colorless liquid 1H NMR (CDCl3) δ 7.70
(s, 1H), 7.00 (s, 1H), 5.10 (br, 2H), 2.85 (m, 2H), 1.25 (m, 3H). MS
(m/z): 264, (M+H2O)+.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

potent selective androgen receptor modulators

$DATUM (f) Thiolate Additions on Enones. The tricyclic enone (1 equiv) was
dissolved in anhydrous toluene (10 mL/mmol), and the thiol (2 equiv) was
added to it. The resulting solution was stirred in the presence of
catalytic amount of DMAP until the reaction showed completion by TLC
(typically takes about 12-24 h). Thereafter the solvent was removed in
vacuo, and the adduct was purified by silica gel column chromatography
using ethyl acetate and light petroleum (60-80 °C). Compound 18a, yield
90%. 60-80 °C; [α]D (CH2Cl2, c 0.3) = +59.2°. IR (cm-1): 1747. 1H NMR
(200 MHz, CDCl3): 1.22 (t, 3 H, J = 7.31 Hz), 2.48-2.64 (m, 3 H),
2.70-2.83 (m, 2 H), 3.08 (m, 1 H), 3.32 (m, 2 H), 3.70 (m, 1 H),
3.86-4.02 (m, 3 H), 4.70 (ABq, 2 H, J = 12.56 Hz), 5.30 (d, 1 H, J = 7.44
Hz), 7.20 (m, 14 H), 7.42- 7.53 (m, 6 H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ
14.6, 24.1, 29.7, 46.2, 48.6, 50.1, 52.2, 65.5, 69.0, 69.3, 73.2, 86.8,
93.9, 96.6, 127.0-128.8, 137.2, 144.0, 211.8. Anal. Calcd for C38H38O5S:
C, 75.22; H, 6.31; S, 5.28. Found: C, 75.59; H, 6.25; S, 5.34.

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: (f) Thiolate Additions on Enones. The
tricyclic enone (1 equiv) was dissolved in anhydrous toluene (10
mL/mmol), and the thiol (2 equiv) was added to it. The resulting solution
was stirred in the presence of catalytic amount of DMAP until the
reaction showed completion by TLC (typically takes about 12-24 h).
Thereafter the solvent was removed in vacuo, and the adduct was purified
by silica gel column chromatography using ethyl acetate and light
petroleum (60-80 °C). Compound 19a, yield 90%. [α]D (CH2Cl2, c 3.5) =
-95.9°. IR (cm-1): 1749. 1H NMR (200 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.48 (t, 3 H, J =
7.48 Hz), 2.55- 2.78 (m, 4 H), 2.85 (dd, 1 H, J = 1.77, 18.77 Hz), 3.00
(dd, 1 H, J = 7.27, 10.70 Hz), 3.70-4.13 (m, 5 H), 4.60 (ABq, 2 H, J =
11.60 Hz), 5.26 (s, 1 H), 7.30 (m, 5 H). 13C NMR (50 MHz, CDCl3): δ 14.7,
23.8, 44.1, 48.4, 51.2, 53.7, 58.2, 69.4, 73.3, 80.3, 94.8, 128.0, 128.5,
137.1, 211.3. Anal. Calcd for C18H22O4S: C, 64.65; H, 6.63; S, 9.59.

by silica gel column chromatography using ethyl acetate and light
petroleum (60-80 °C). Compound 20a, yield 90%. [α]D (CHCl3, c 0.48) =
+10.04°. IR (cm-1): 1747. 1H NMR (200 MHz, CDCl3): δ 1.24 (t, 3 H, J =
7.42 Hz), 2.50- 2.89 (m, 5 H), 3.04 (dd, 1 H, J = 6.95, 10.97 Hz), 3.27
(dd, 1 H, J = 4.03, 9.99 Hz), 3.45 (dd, 1 H, J = 7.57, 9.97 Hz), 3.70
(dd, 1 H, J = 2.14, 6.84 Hz), 3.77 (ABq, 2 H, J = 9.10 Hz), 4.24 (m, 1
H), 4.74 (ABq, 2 H, J = 11.47 Hz), 5.36 (s, 1 H), 7.10-7.52 (m, 20 H).
13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 14.7, 23.9, 45.9, 48.3, 51.3, 53.2, 64.0,
66.3, 69.0, 74.2, 80.9, 86.7, 95.5, 127.0-128.7, 137.2, 144.0, 211.1.
Anal. Calcd for C38H38O5S: C, 75.22; H, 6.31; S, 5.28. Found: C, 75.45;
H, 6.13; S, 5.34.

$DATUM 865-48-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General procedure for the stoichiometric reaction of arylpalladium halide
complexes (2 and 3a-b) with thiols in the presence of NaOtBu. Into an NMR
tube with a septum-lined screw cap was placed NaOtBu (0.036 mmol) and 0.5
mL of the stock solution A. The corresponding thiol (0.024 mmol) was
injected into the NMR tube and 31P{1H} NMR spectra were obtained. The
starting material was consumed in less than 5 min in all the cases. The
yield of the sulfide was determined by GC analysis. entry 1.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Resting State and Elementary Steps of the Coupling of Aryl Halides with
Thiols Catalyzed by Alkylbisphosphine Complexes of Palladium
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Alvaro, Elsa; Hartwig, John F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131(22), 7858-7868

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME276 STEP1

$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the stoichiometric
reaction of arylpalladium halide complexes (2 and 3a-b) with thiols in
the presence of NaOtBu. Into an NMR tube with a septum-lined screw cap
was placed NaOtBu (0.036 mmol) and 0.5 mL of the stock solution A. The
corresponding thiol (0.024 mmol) was injected into the NMR tube and
31P{1H} NMR spectra were obtained. The starting material was consumed in
less than 5 min in all the cases. The yield of the sulfide was determined
by GC analysis.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Resting State and Elementary Steps of the Coupling of Aryl Halides with
Thiols Catalyzed by Alkylbisphosphine Complexes of Palladium
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Alvaro, Elsa; Hartwig, John F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131(22), 7858-7868

$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for the stoichiometric
reaction of arylpalladium halide complexes (2 and 3a-b) with thiols in
the presence of NaOtBu. Into an NMR tube with a septum-lined screw cap
was placed NaOtBu (0.036 mmol) and 0.5 mL of the stock solution A. The
corresponding thiol (0.024 mmol) was injected into the NMR tube and
31P{1H} NMR spectra were obtained. The starting material was consumed in
less than 5 min in all the cases. The yield of the sulfide was determined
by GC analysis. entry 3.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Resting State and Elementary Steps of the Coupling of Aryl Halides with
Thiols Catalyzed by Alkylbisphosphine Complexes of Palladium
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Alvaro, Elsa; Hartwig, John F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131(22), 7858-7868

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME279 STEP1

  2  2
$MOL

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Removal of the Tsv Group. Method A. A suspension of dodecanethiol (1.5
equiv) and NaH (3.0 equiv) in CH3CN was added to a solution of the
protected substrate in anhyd CH3CN (0.1 M). The resulting mixture was
stirred at the temperature shown in Table 4 until TLC indicated complete
consumption of the starting material. The reaction was quenched with
water, neutralized with 0.5 M aqueous HCl, and extracted with CH2Cl2. The
combined organic extracts were washed with brine, dried over MgSO4,
filtered, and concentrated. The residue was purified by flash column
chromatography on silica gel. Compound 1a, yield 98%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, the reaction progress was monitored by TLC
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Tosvinyl and Besvinyl as Protecting Groups of Imides, Azinones,
Nucleosides, Sultams, and Lactams. Catalytic Conjugate Additions to
Tosylacetylene
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Petit, Elena; Bosch, Lluis; Font, Joan; Mola, Laura; Costa, Anna M.;
Vilarrasa, Jaume
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2014), 79(18), 8826-8834

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 108-88-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for catalytic C-S coupling
reactions. 1 (121 μL of 0.04 M stock solution in toluene, 0.0049 mmol)
was combined with aryl halide (0.18 mmol) and NaOtBu (31 mg, 0.36 mmol)
in a screw cap vial with a stir bar and dissolved in toluene (1.0 mL).
The thiol reagent (0.16 mmol) was added to the sample along with the
internal standard. For reactions with Fsubstituted aryl halides,
benzotrifluoride (CF3C6H5) was used as the internal standard. For
reactions with CF3-substituted aryl halides, fluorobenzene was used as
the internal standard. Mesitylene was used as the internal standard for
reactions containing no fluorine substituents. The reaction vial was
sealed and heated in a 110°C oil bath. Reactions were monitored by 19F
NMR or 1H NMR spectroscopy. Preparative scale reactions were performed by
combining 1 (15 mg, 0.032 mmol), aryl halide (1.1 mmol), and NaOt Bu (192
mg, 2 mmol) in a screw cap vial with a teflon stir bar and dissolved in
toluene. The thiol reagent (1.0 mmol) was then added. For product
isolation, the sample was passed through a pad of Celite/silica gel and
the volatiles were removed by vacuum. Products were identified by 1H NMR
spectroscopy and the spectra for the known compounds were compared to
those reported in the literature. 6 (CH3(CH2)9)S(p-C6H4F) (t). 1H NMR
(C6D6): δ 7.07 (m, 2H), 6.67 (m, 2H), 2.58 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 1.46 (m,
2H), 1.24 (m, 14H), 0.91 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 3H); 19F NMR (C6D6): δ -117.0
(m); 13C{1H} NMR (C6D6): δ 161.9 (d, J FC = 245 Hz), 132.6 (d, J FC = 3.4
Hz), 132.1 (d, J FC = 7.5 Hz), 116.1 (d, J FC = 22 Hz), 35.0, 32.3, 30.0,
29.9, 29.8, 29.6, 29.5, 29.1, 23.1, 14.4.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, scalable, screw-cap vial used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A Well-Defined (POCOP)Rh Catalyst for the Coupling of Aryl Halides with
Thiols
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Timpa, Samuel D.; Pell, Christopher J.; Ozerov, Oleg V.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136(42), 14772-14779

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for catalytic C-S coupling
reactions. 1 (121 μL of 0.04 M stock solution in toluene, 0.0049 mmol)
was combined with aryl halide (0.18 mmol) and NaOtBu (31 mg, 0.36 mmol)
in a screw cap vial with a stir bar and dissolved in toluene (1.0 mL).
The thiol reagent (0.16 mmol) was added to the sample along with the
internal standard. For reactions with Fsubstituted aryl halides,
benzotrifluoride (CF3C6H5) was used as the internal standard. For
reactions with CF3-substituted aryl halides, fluorobenzene was used as
the internal standard. Mesitylene was used as the internal standard for
reactions containing no fluorine substituents. The reaction vial was
sealed and heated in a 110°C oil bath. Reactions were monitored by 19F
NMR or 1H NMR spectroscopy. Preparative scale reactions were performed by
combining 1 (15 mg, 0.032 mmol), aryl halide (1.1 mmol), and NaOt Bu (192
mg, 2 mmol) in a screw cap vial with a teflon stir bar and dissolved in
toluene. The thiol reagent (1.0 mmol) was then added. For product
isolation, the sample was passed through a pad of Celite/silica gel and
the volatiles were removed by vacuum. Products were identified by 1H NMR
spectroscopy and the spectra for the known compounds were compared to
those reported in the literature. 6 (CH3(CH2)4)S(p-C6H4CF3) (w). 1H NMR
(C6D6): δ 7.19 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 6.93 (d, J = 9.5 Hz, 2H), 2.49 (t, J
= 7.5 Hz, 2H), 1.38 (m, 2H), 1.12 (m, 4H), 0.78 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 3H); 19F
NMR (C6D6): δ -62.8 (s); 13C{1H} NMR (C6D6): δ 143.5 (q, J FC = 1.5 Hz),
127.2 (s), 127.1 (q, J FC = 33 Hz), 125.8 (q, J FC = 3.8 Hz), 125.0 (q, J
FC = 397 Hz), 32.2 (s), 31.2 (s), 28.6 (s), 22.5 (s), 14.0 (s).

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Removal of the Tsv Group. Method A. A
suspension of dodecanethiol (1.5 equiv) and NaH (3.0 equiv) in CH3CN was
added to a solution of the protected substrate in anhyd CH3CN (0.1 M).
The resulting mixture was stirred at the temperature shown in Table 4
until TLC indicated complete consumption of the starting material. The
reaction was quenched with water, neutralized with 0.5 M aqueous HCl, and
extracted with CH2Cl2. The combined organic extracts were washed with
brine, dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was
purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel. Compound 1c, yield
97%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, the reaction progress was monitored by TLC

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for catalytic C-S coupling
reactions. 1 (121 μL of 0.04 M stock solution in toluene, 0.0049 mmol)
was combined with aryl halide (0.18 mmol) and NaOtBu (31 mg, 0.36 mmol)
in a screw cap vial with a stir bar and dissolved in toluene (1.0 mL).
The thiol reagent (0.16 mmol) was added to the sample along with the
internal standard. For reactions with Fsubstituted aryl halides,
benzotrifluoride (CF3C6H5) was used as the internal standard. For
reactions with CF3-substituted aryl halides, fluorobenzene was used as
the internal standard. Mesitylene was used as the internal standard for
reactions containing no fluorine substituents. The reaction vial was
sealed and heated in a 110°C oil bath. Reactions were monitored by 19F
NMR or 1H NMR spectroscopy. Preparative scale reactions were performed by
combining 1 (15 mg, 0.032 mmol), aryl halide (1.1 mmol), and NaOt Bu (192
mg, 2 mmol) in a screw cap vial with a teflon stir bar and dissolved in
toluene. The thiol reagent (1.0 mmol) was then added. For product
isolation, the sample was passed through a pad of Celite/silica gel and
the volatiles were removed by vacuum. Products were identified by 1H NMR
spectroscopy and the spectra for the known compounds were compared to
those reported in the literature. 6 (CH3(CH2)9)S(p-C6H4CF3) (u). 1H NMR
(C6D6): δ 7.19 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 6.95 (d, J = 9.5 Hz 2H), 2.53 (t, J =
7.5 Hz, 2H), 1.44 (m, 2H), 1.23 (m, 14H), 0.91 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 3H); 19F
NMR (C6D6): δ -62.8 (s). 13C{1H} NMR (C6D6): δ 143.6 (s), 127.3 (s),
127.2 (q, J FC = 32.5 Hz), 125.8 (q, J FC = 3.8 Hz), 125.0 (q, J FC = 272
Hz), 32.4 (s), 32.3 (s), 30.03 (s), 29.96 (s), 29.8 (s), 29.6 (s), 29.2
(s), 29.1 (s), 23.2 (s), 14.4 (s)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, scalable, screw-cap vial used

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 865-48-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 1023743-21-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 108-88-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for catalytic C-S coupling
reactions. 1 (121 μL of 0.04 M stock solution in toluene, 0.0049 mmol)
was combined with aryl halide (0.18 mmol) and NaOtBu (31 mg, 0.36 mmol)
in a screw cap vial with a stir bar and dissolved in toluene (1.0 mL).
The thiol reagent (0.16 mmol) was added to the sample along with the
internal standard. For reactions with Fsubstituted aryl halides,
benzotrifluoride (CF3C6H5) was used as the internal standard. For
reactions with CF3-substituted aryl halides, fluorobenzene was used as
the internal standard. Mesitylene was used as the internal standard for
reactions containing no fluorine substituents. The reaction vial was
sealed and heated in a 110°C oil bath. Reactions were monitored by 19F
NMR or 1H NMR spectroscopy. Preparative scale reactions were performed by
combining 1 (15 mg, 0.032 mmol), aryl halide (1.1 mmol), and NaOt Bu (192
mg, 2 mmol) in a screw cap vial with a teflon stir bar and dissolved in
toluene. The thiol reagent (1.0 mmol) was then added. For product
isolation, the sample was passed through a pad of Celite/silica gel and
the volatiles were removed by vacuum. Products were identified by 1H NMR
spectroscopy and the spectra for the known compounds were compared to
those reported in the literature. 6 (CH3(CH2)4)S(p-C6H4F) (v). 1H NMR
(C6D6): δ 7.05 (m, 2H), 6.67 (m, 2H), 2.54 (t, J = 8.0 Hz), 1.41 (m, 2H),
1.14 (m, 4H), 0.78 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 3H); 19F NMR (C6D6): δ -117.0 (m).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, scalable, screw-cap vial used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A Well-Defined (POCOP)Rh Catalyst for the Coupling of Aryl Halides with
Thiols
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Timpa, Samuel D.; Pell, Christopher J.; Ozerov, Oleg V.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136(42), 14772-14779

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME289 STEP1

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for catalytic C-S coupling
reactions. 1 (121 μL of 0.04 M stock solution in toluene, 0.0049 mmol)
was combined with aryl halide (0.18 mmol) and NaOtBu (31 mg, 0.36 mmol)
in a screw cap vial with a stir bar and dissolved in toluene (1.0 mL).
The thiol reagent (0.16 mmol) was added to the sample along with the
internal standard. For reactions with Fsubstituted aryl halides,
benzotrifluoride (CF3C6H5) was used as the internal standard. For
reactions with CF3-substituted aryl halides, fluorobenzene was used as
the internal standard. Mesitylene was used as the internal standard for
reactions containing no fluorine substituents. The reaction vial was
sealed and heated in a 110°C oil bath. Reactions were monitored by 19F
NMR or 1H NMR spectroscopy. Preparative scale reactions were performed by
combining 1 (15 mg, 0.032 mmol), aryl halide (1.1 mmol), and NaOt Bu (192
mg, 2 mmol) in a screw cap vial with a teflon stir bar and dissolved in
toluene. The thiol reagent (1.0 mmol) was then added. For product
isolation, the sample was passed through a pad of Celite/silica gel and
the volatiles were removed by vacuum. Products were identified by 1H NMR
spectroscopy and the spectra for the known compounds were compared to
those reported in the literature. 6 (CH3(CH2)9)S(p-C6H4F) (t). 1H NMR
(C6D6): δ 7.07 (m, 2H), 6.67 (m, 2H), 2.58 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 1.46 (m,
2H), 1.24 (m, 14H), 0.91 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 3H); 19F NMR (C6D6): δ -117.0
(m); 13C{1H} NMR (C6D6): δ 161.9 (d, J FC = 245 Hz), 132.6 (d, J FC = 3.4
Hz), 132.1 (d, J FC = 7.5 Hz), 116.1 (d, J FC = 22 Hz), 35.0, 32.3, 30.0,
29.9, 29.8, 29.6, 29.5, 29.1, 23.1, 14.4.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, scalable, screw-cap vial used

$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 865-48-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 108-88-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Synthesis of (POCOP)Rh(p-C6H4Me)(SnC5H11) (15a) and
(POCOP)Rh(Sp-C6H4Me(nC5H11) (15b). 1 (65 mg, 0.135 mmol) was dissolved in
toluene and treated with NaOtBu (14 mg, 0.15 mmol) and p-BrC6H4Me (18 μL,
0.14 mmol) . The reaction was stirred for 15 m at RT. The reaction
mixture was then treated with NaOtBu (14 mg, 0.15 mmol) and HSnC5H11 (18
μL, 0.14 mmol). The reaction was stirred for 5 m at RT before being
filtered through a pad of silica and Celite and the volatiles were
removed under vacuum. The resulting purple solid was dissolved in C6D6.
Analysis by 31P{1H} NMR showed the formation of two products
(POCOP)Rh(p-C6H4Me)(SnC5H11) (15a) and (POCOP)Rh(Sp-C6H4Me(nC5H11) (15b).
Heating the reaction mixture at 80 °C for 15 min. 95% conversion to 15b.
The 95 : 5 distribution of 15b : 15a did not change over a period of 3 h
and 45 min. 15b. 31P{1H} NMR (C6D6): δ 176.0 (d, 173 Hz); 1H NMR (C6D6):
δ 7.69 (d, 8 Hz, 2H, C6H4Me), 7.00 (t, 8 Hz, 1H, POCOP), 6.91 (d, 7.5 Hz,
2H, POCOP), 6.84 (d, 8 Hz, 2H, C6H4Me), 2.89 (t, 7 Hz, 2H, Pent), 1.97
(s, 3H, C6H4Me), 1.95 (m, 4H, CHMe2), 1.48 (m, 2H, Pent), 1.29 (q, 6.5
Hz, 12H, CHMe2), 1.20 (q, 8 Hz, 12H, CHMe2), 1.18 (m, 4H, Pent), 0.78 (t,
7 Hz, 3H, Pent). 13C{1H} NMR (C6D6): δ 167.5 (t, J PC = 9.5 Hz, POCOP),
141.7 (dt, J RhC = 33.8 Hz, J CP = 10 Hz, POCOP), 138.7 (s), 135.5 (s),
133.6 (s), 129.5 (s), 124.6 (s), 104.1 (t, J CP = 6.8 Hz, POCOP), 48.7
(t, J CP = 5.7 Hz, Pent), 30.9 (s, Pent), 30.7 (t, J CP = 10 Hz, POCOP),
29.3 (s, Pent), 22.7 (s, Pent), 18.7 (t, J CP = 4.4 Hz, POCOP), 17.6
(POCOP), 14.1 (s, Pent).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A Well-Defined (POCOP)Rh Catalyst for the Coupling of Aryl Halides with
Thiols
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DATUM 75-05-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Removal of the Tsv Group. Method A. A
suspension of dodecanethiol (1.5 equiv) and NaH (3.0 equiv) in CH3CN was
added to a solution of the protected substrate in anhyd CH3CN (0.1 M).
The resulting mixture was stirred at the temperature shown in Table 4
until TLC indicated complete consumption of the starting material. The
reaction was quenched with water, neutralized with 0.5 M aqueous HCl, and
extracted with CH2Cl2. The combined organic extracts were washed with
brine, dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was
purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel. Compound 1b, yield
95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, the reaction progress was monitored by TLC
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General Procedure for the Formation of Disulfides. To a solution of
Burgess reagent (1.05 equiv) in benzene (1 M) was added dropwise the
corresponding thiol (1 equiv) dissolved in benzene at room temperature.
The progress of the reaction was followed by GC/MS. After complete
conversion of the starting material (approximately 30 min to 1 h), the
reaction mixture was filtered through a plug of silica (hexanes). The
crude product was either triturated with hexanes or purified by flash
column chromatography. Didecyl Disulfide (2) [CAS 10496-18-1]. Following
the general procedure using decanethiol (0.59 mL, 2.86 mmol) as starting
material gave 0.47 g of didecyl disulfide (95%): 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3)
δ 2.70 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H), 1.78-1.64 (m, 4H), 1.42- 1.29 (m, 28H), 0.90
(t, J = 6.8 Hz, 6H); 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3) δ 39.2, 31.9, 29.6, 29.5,
29.3, 29.2, 28.8, 28.5, 22.7, 14.4; LRMS (EI) m/z 347 (M + 1, 25.4), 346
(M+, 87.5), 278 (18.9), 206 (14.0), 173 (10.0), 140 (14.3), 139 (37.7),
125 (11.0), 101 (11.1), 97 (20.1), 96 (13.2), 95 (11.1), 91 (34.7), 87
(20.5), 85 (48.3), 84 (10.3), 83 (21.2), 71 (48.7), 70 (24.2), 69 (34.4),
68 (10.2), 67 (11.7), 60 (11.4), 57 (97.8), 56 (19.9), 55 (60.9), 47
(10.4), 45 (13.1), 43 (100.0), 42 (12.1), 41 (49.9); HRMS (EI) m/z calcd
for C20H42S2 346.2728, found 346.2727.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM yield depends on reaction conditions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Unexpected Reactivity of the Burgess Reagent with Thiols: Synthesis of
Symmetrical Disulfides

$DATUM 108-88-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for catalytic C-S coupling
reactions. 1 (121 μL of 0.04 M stock solution in toluene, 0.0049 mmol)
was combined with aryl halide (0.18 mmol) and NaOtBu (31 mg, 0.36 mmol)
in a screw cap vial with a stir bar and dissolved in toluene (1.0 mL).
The thiol reagent (0.16 mmol) was added to the sample along with the
internal standard. For reactions with Fsubstituted aryl halides,
benzotrifluoride (CF3C6H5) was used as the internal standard. For
reactions with CF3-substituted aryl halides, fluorobenzene was used as
the internal standard. Mesitylene was used as the internal standard for
reactions containing no fluorine substituents. The reaction vial was
sealed and heated in a 110°C oil bath. Reactions were monitored by 19F
NMR or 1H NMR spectroscopy. Preparative scale reactions were performed by
combining 1 (15 mg, 0.032 mmol), aryl halide (1.1 mmol), and NaOt Bu (192
mg, 2 mmol) in a screw cap vial with a teflon stir bar and dissolved in
toluene. The thiol reagent (1.0 mmol) was then added. For product
isolation, the sample was passed through a pad of Celite/silica gel and
the volatiles were removed by vacuum. Products were identified by 1H NMR
spectroscopy and the spectra for the known compounds were compared to
those reported in the literature. 6 (CH3(CH2)4)S(p-C6H4F) (v). 1H NMR
(C6D6): δ 7.05 (m, 2H), 6.67 (m, 2H), 2.54 (t, J = 8.0 Hz), 1.41 (m, 2H),
1.14 (m, 4H), 0.78 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 3H); 19F NMR (C6D6): δ -117.0 (m).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, scalable, screw-cap vial used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A Well-Defined (POCOP)Rh Catalyst for the Coupling of Aryl Halides with
Thiols
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Timpa, Samuel D.; Pell, Christopher J.; Ozerov, Oleg V.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136(42), 14772-14779

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 108-88-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General procedure for catalytic C-S coupling
reactions. 1 (121 μL of 0.04 M stock solution in toluene, 0.0049 mmol)
was combined with aryl halide (0.18 mmol) and NaOtBu (31 mg, 0.36 mmol)
in a screw cap vial with a stir bar and dissolved in toluene (1.0 mL).
The thiol reagent (0.16 mmol) was added to the sample along with the
internal standard. For reactions with Fsubstituted aryl halides,
benzotrifluoride (CF3C6H5) was used as the internal standard. For
reactions with CF3-substituted aryl halides, fluorobenzene was used as
the internal standard. Mesitylene was used as the internal standard for
reactions containing no fluorine substituents. The reaction vial was
sealed and heated in a 110°C oil bath. Reactions were monitored by 19F
NMR or 1H NMR spectroscopy. Preparative scale reactions were performed by
combining 1 (15 mg, 0.032 mmol), aryl halide (1.1 mmol), and NaOt Bu (192
mg, 2 mmol) in a screw cap vial with a teflon stir bar and dissolved in
toluene. The thiol reagent (1.0 mmol) was then added. For product
isolation, the sample was passed through a pad of Celite/silica gel and
the volatiles were removed by vacuum. Products were identified by 1H NMR
spectroscopy and the spectra for the known compounds were compared to
those reported in the literature. 6 (CH3(CH2)4)S(p-C6H4CF3) (w). 1H NMR
(C6D6): δ 7.19 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 6.93 (d, J = 9.5 Hz, 2H), 2.49 (t, J
= 7.5 Hz, 2H), 1.38 (m, 2H), 1.12 (m, 4H), 0.78 (t, J = 8.0 Hz, 3H); 19F
NMR (C6D6): δ -62.8 (s); 13C{1H} NMR (C6D6): δ 143.5 (q, J FC = 1.5 Hz),
127.2 (s), 127.1 (q, J FC = 33 Hz), 125.8 (q, J FC = 3.8 Hz), 125.0 (q, J
FC = 397 Hz), 32.2 (s), 31.2 (s), 28.6 (s), 22.5 (s), 14.0 (s).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, scalable, screw-cap vial used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A Well-Defined (POCOP)Rh Catalyst for the Coupling of Aryl Halides with
Thiols
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Timpa, Samuel D.; Pell, Christopher J.; Ozerov, Oleg V.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136(42), 14772-14779

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Removal of the Tsv Group. Method A. A
suspension of dodecanethiol (1.5 equiv) and NaH (3.0 equiv) in CH3CN was
added to a solution of the protected substrate in anhyd CH3CN (0.1 M).
The resulting mixture was stirred at the temperature shown in Table 4
until TLC indicated complete consumption of the starting material. The
reaction was quenched with water, neutralized with 0.5 M aqueous HCl, and
extracted with CH2Cl2. The combined organic extracts were washed with
brine, dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was
purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel. Compound 1a, yield
92%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, the reaction progress was monitored by TLC
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Tosvinyl and Besvinyl as Protecting Groups of Imides, Azinones,
Nucleosides, Sultams, and Lactams. Catalytic Conjugate Additions to
Tosylacetylene

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Removal of the Tsv Group. Method A. A
suspension of dodecanethiol (1.5 equiv) and NaH (3.0 equiv) in CH3CN was
added to a solution of the protected substrate in anhyd CH3CN (0.1 M).
The resulting mixture was stirred at the temperature shown in Table 4
until TLC indicated complete consumption of the starting material. The
reaction was quenched with water, neutralized with 0.5 M aqueous HCl, and
extracted with CH2Cl2. The combined organic extracts were washed with
brine, dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated. The residue was
purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel. Yield 90%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM alternative preparation shown, the reaction progress was monitored by TLC
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Tosvinyl and Besvinyl as Protecting Groups of Imides, Azinones,
Nucleosides, Sultams, and Lactams. Catalytic Conjugate Additions to
Tosylacetylene
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Petit, Elena; Bosch, Lluis; Font, Joan; Mola, Laura; Costa, Anna M.;
Vilarrasa, Jaume
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2014), 79(18), 8826-8834
